149875525.review:
Me: Can I play Diablo?
Mom: We have Diablo at home.
Diablo at home:

-------------------

While Torchlight II may take the spotlight these days, especially with the perceived disappointment of Torchlight III, the original Torchlight is an underrated gem. The music and sound design, recorded and composed by Diablo's Matt Uelmen, seamlessly blends the atmospheric charm of Diablo 1 & 2 with a refreshing touch of newer instrumentation and production techniques.

The game's simplicity, easy to understand interface, and familiar mechanics make it accessible to both newcomers and seasoned players. There's quite a few things that will feel clunky, out of date, and rough around the edges, especially the lack of settings made available to the player, but nothing that hurts the overall experience too much.

For those seeking a straightforward Diablo-like experience, Torchlight remains a solid choice especially when it's on sale. Click bad guys and explore dungeons.

149265398.review:
A very obvious D2 clone that does it worse. The "crafting" options feel pointless and added last minute - and the imbue system feels out of whack. Half the time I would get "nothing" or something minor like a slot (I didn't use slots until the final boss - just because I was done). I've lost several "decent" and hundreds of thousands of gold to this mechanism. The quest rewards were pretty useless too. 

The gold in vs out ratio was insane. I accidentally sold my best item for under 500 gold, and it costs me half of my current wealth. It was frustrating. 

The story is meagre at best. Hopefully TL2 does better.

Alphonse: (Excited) Yeah, Torchlight is so much fun! And I don't even need to eat, so I can keep playing!

144353621.review:
First, I'd like to say that I have not played any of the Diablo games. Yes, I know, how can I even be on here writing a review if I haven't played Diablo? It's like writing a film review when you've never seen Star Wars or Citizen Kane.

Yeah, exactly.

Now with that out of the way, I really wanted to like this game, I really did. It does not stand the test of time to gameplay or even a purposeful storyline (big bad is evil and will destroy town of people you hardly interact with). It is VERY simple, and that's fine, but I'd rather be playing Baldur's Gate 1 rather than this as in my playthrough as a Vanquisher, I was able to go through the whole thing with one special attack and a smattering of points abilities to other places. I finished it on Hard, the loot was a bit meh and didn't really level up to where I was at the time, and the mob rushes just became a case of 'oh here we go again, run away, turn and shoot, run away, turn and shoot'. 

So, I found it boring. Which is terrible for a game but there you go. With Diablo you don't even have to play the game without knowing that the writers have invested heavily into game lore as they were going along with it. So for Torchlight I'd play it for the mindlessness of it inbetween playing something else as well. The background music isn't bad at least though, so that's something. Back in the day I may have liked this, but tastes, technology and expectations change. So in 2023, I can't recommend this.

143701919.review:
Neat little Diablo Clone with an interesting artstyle, moody music, rounded gameplay and a semi-satisfying lootspiral, but with some annoying hickups with the dodgy hitboxes. Just don't expect an actual Diablo or Titan Quest out of this. Also, the balance is pretty whack, see below for a sanity-saving tip: 

So the game suggests to play on hard if you're an ARPG veteran. Fair enough. But, what it doesn't tell you is that you will encounter enemies that will simply two-shot and even one-shot you on a regular basis. You will die, a lot. Despite having tons of potions on you. And the punishment for death gets really steep later on. BUT: You can work around that by using the town portal spell (or scrolls) to make manual checkpoints, then choose the "revive in town" option which negates the death penalty completely and then reutrn through the town portal to where you were before. Trust me, you'll need this. You forget to set a town portal checkpoint, you will lose a lot of money OR have to slog through up to 4 levels that you've cleared before.

143683112.review:
Can't recommend this one.

What you can't expect for a 2009 game:
- Lackluster menu.
- Dum as hell (no pun intended) AI.
- Extremely low variety of enemy types (combined with bad AI),
- Padding (the game has 35 levels but actually it's 7 times of 3 to 5 identical levels with the same enemy types and some empty levels with waypoints).
- Unimpactful loot and skills.
- Damage sponges bosses (specially the two bosses in the end).

Pros I could find:
- Graphics are OK, not 2009 OK but OK.
- It's an oversimplified torchlight 2, as an entry level to isometric arpgs (but why? just play Diablo or TL2).
- Has an infinite dungeon mode after beating the main campaign (if you still want to keep playing for some reason),
- It's very short, (but it drags too much).
- It's mod-able (still better play TL2),

It has so many bad design choices for a 2009 game with so many good examples out there,
In the end it felt like AereA but with mobs that at least can do some damage.

141845194.review:
Torchlight is NOT a good game. This is a game heavily inspired by a previous ARPG known as 'Fate' where you dove into a town dungeon with a pet companion. The huge difference is that while Fate was random generation, Torchlight decided to make a standardized experience for Players with non-randomized Bosses, Floors, and Quests. Overall I'm still fond of starting the game and going through the first couple of floors however it's as the game continues that it starts to become a chore. This is a game I've quit multiple times and just never brought myself to finish, and here I am again not finishing the game for one final time.


On level up the Player is given three stat points to distribute between Strength, Dexterity, Magic, and Block. Strength is exclusive to Melee Damage, Dexterity to Ranged Damage, Magic to Elemental Damage, and Block to Physical Damage Absorption. The only way to obtain Elemental Damage Absorption is through item resistances. Also on leveling either by XP or FAME (Earned by killing Champions), the player is given a Talent point. Of the three classes in Torchlight there are MANY overlapping skills in the Talent Tree as any Passive is shared between Classes. There are 15 Passive Skills out of 30-33 Skills and Passives ultimately being skills you are forced to take like +Critical Chance. The Talent Tree is level locked and each Talent can be upgraded 10 times each. A majority of these skill points are regulated to the Passive Skills as you'll only use 1-2 Actives. Outside of this there are General Skills that any class can learn such as: Summons, Heals, Fireball/Ice Shard, and Offensive/Defensive Buffs. Concerning builds this results in most people running the same General Skills + Passives with the only flavor being whichever Active Talent Skill you choose to spam.


As this is an ARPG of course there are items with multiple rarities and sets. You'll find that Legendary Items do no massive change to any playstyle, simply being a stronger item. Items can be enchanted with a ~2% debuff chance (increasing on success) that purges the item, not including the %chance of failure without debuff. I take issue with this feature as I've had multiple items be purged on the first attempt, the very FIRST one. There are also consumables like Fish and Potions. Fish have temporary effects like increasing resistances or experience gain. Potions are the age-old heal or restore mana.


As the game proceeds the levels begin to grow in size but the layouts and enemies are becoming more and more annoying. Playing on Very Hard it became a chore as enemies with instant abilities hiding in corners results in Player passivity and makes each floor take even longer to complete. The Dark Zealot is a game ruining enemy that plagues the late-game but it's best if we just go to the list of complaints:


- Enemy abilities are ridiculous to the nth degree as they can instantly trigger their abilities which make them unavoidable for the player. This is especially bad on certain spawns where you can have LOTS of these enemies in a closed location that you have to walk into. Which means you walk into a room, or over a bridge, or upstairs and die instantly.


- Dark Zealots are absolutely busted with three spells: poison bolts, summon skeletons, and the most important: lightning bolt aka goodbye world of the living. There doesn't seem to be a CD on these abilities and they can use them more than once in a row. The issue is that the lightning bolt does around 1-2k damage but they can also CRIT on this ability and do ~3.5k. My character had 1.6k HP and for reference there is NO health scaling through Talents or Attributes, only Items that CAN have +### HP. 


So okay we need Lightning Resistances to survive right? Well wait! Elemental Resistances are a FLAT amount and to try and cover for the crit damage... it'd require that we have ~2k Lightning Resistance. So okay I'm just being a moron right? Surely? Well let me look at my legendary equipment: +30 Lightning Resistance. Let's suppose I manage to get +30 Lightning Resistance on ALL of my items (10), which means 300 total. Okay we're nowhere close. Well let's say I manage to Socket all 10 item slots with 2 gems (20) AND I manage to get the best quality/rarity of gem (Eternal: +28 Resist) AND I use the Elemental Resistance Skill at max level (+47): I'd have a grand total of 907. Do you get it yet? Sure at this amount I'd manage to survive the normal Lightning Bolt, but IF the enemy ever crits it's a insta-kill. Which I have to reiterate that obtaining ANY of the items or gems like I'd suggested is near impossible. At the point of fighting Ordrak (Final Boss) I STILL did not have a single Eternal gem of any type. So getting 20 of those gems of a specific type or let alone getting 2 sockets on all the armor pieces (with the highest lightning resist roll + having health increases) is complete insanity. But wait wait wait, I still haven't gotten to the best part:


THESE DARK ZEALOTS ARE A NORMAL SPAWN. 


Just let that sink in for a bit. They can spawn in groups and do more damage on average than the Champion version of the same type. The only advice I saw in years of this game being released is to either pray for a projectile deflect% or silence them before they can cast (which again they can be off-screen and cast as soon as they're in range). What an absolute shit enemy that ruins the game. The best argument is to go into Health and try to out-scale the damage but again you can only find health gains through Item Stats which is entirely RNG.


- Bosses are agonizing (Very Hard Difficulty) as their health is bloated. Ordrak for example can infinitely spawn enemies for ever and ever and after fighting the boss for ~10-15 minutes, I'd only done around 4-5% of his total health-bar. This is coming immediately after Alric (who can ALSO spawn infinite enemies) that I was forced to kill with a melee weapon because for some godforsaken reason, the Devs decided to give him a skill that gave him and all of his minions immunity to any ranged attack. So I was able to easily kill Alric with a trashy merchant item and the boss in the immediate next floor is practically un-killable WITH my proper legendary weapon because of his health being 20x bigger? I don't get it. I thought maybe Ordrak had a special mechanic I was missing but it's just a straight slog. Going off the Torchlight Wiki, a majority of the bosses don't even have weaknesses with most having ~120% to all resistance and armor.


- Ranged Mechanics don't function properly with the Z-Axis and there's a LOT of bridges/stairs. If an enemy is on the stairs right in front of you, you WILL shoot over them. If you try shooting UP the stairs you will instead simply hit the stairs. The only solution is to stand ON the bridge/stairs or try and lure the enemy away. Considering that approaching certain enemies will cause them to use their ability, neither one are practical. Even AoE abilities have a seemingly random chance of being successful on the Z-Axis, as it feels much more minimal in Z-Axis scaling than the X and Y.


- Bad level design on the bridge maps + lava and onward. The start of the game in the caverns then to castle type isn't so bad with straightforward hallways and rooms with clutter. Then you get to the infinite bridges... and thousands upon thousands of staircases. Let me reiterate again that any amount of Z-Axis if using ranged attacks. Not only that but your pet and summons will also get stuck or lost somewhere in the labyrinth. It's not fun or fair and I've never wanted levels to end so quickly. I think in nearly EVERY play-through I've done, these maps are the so to speak 'run killers'. Where I stop playing because the level just kept going and going and there's like 5 more floors of this trash and the fun is just bottoming out.


- Enemies can sometimes be invisible because their model didn't load in.

141832299.review:
This is my favourite Diablo style Arpg.

I hope Torchlight 4 does happen and they return to their solo / single player roots without any stupid online requirements as is with MMOS. 141734404.review:
Great proof of concept of what would ultimately become Torchlight 2. The game itself is alright, if a bit too simplistic and repetitive compared to it's sequel, but I can't deny this game is somewhat addictive and holds a TON of nostalgia for me, this game beautifully captures the Warcraft 3 visual style with the craziness you'd expect from an ARPG. Shouldn't be a surprise considering Runic was composed of ex-Blizzard veterans.

I'd recommend buying TL2 instead, but if you somehow get ahold of this game, I'd say sure, at least give it a fair shake and see what Runic improved in TL2. Maybe you'll sink 20+ hours in a single sitting, who knows! You could do a lot worse for far more expensive games with online only requirements, season passes and tons of microtransactions.

You want Path of Exile without the stress, and you want Diablo without the guilt.

You want heroes like Beef Grease the tank, Katie Knockers the ranger, and Edge Deviantart the wizard.  Anybody who wants more than that can make their own **** game.

138611621.review:
Torchlight 1 is a delightful action RPG that captured my heart from the moment I embarked on my adventure in the town of Torchlight. This game offers a truly captivating experience, and I am thrilled to share my positive review with the gaming community.

First and foremost, the game's visual aesthetics are absolutely stunning. The vibrant and colorful art style creates a lively and immersive world that begs to be explored. Each dungeon, town, and outdoor area is meticulously designed, and the attention to detail is commendable. From the eerie depths of the Ember Mines to the beautiful landscapes of the Estherian Ruins, every location feels unique and brimming with character.

The gameplay mechanics in Torchlight 1 are simply fantastic. The combat is fast-paced, fluid, and incredibly satisfying. Whether you choose to play as a versatile Destroyer, a mystical Alchemist, or a nimble Vanquisher, each class offers a distinct playstyle, ensuring there's something for everyone. The ability to customize your character's skills and attributes allows for a truly personalized experience, making each playthrough feel fresh and exciting.

One aspect that truly sets Torchlight 1 apart is its addictive loot system. The game is a treasure trove of magical weapons, armor, and enchantments. Unleashing devastating combos with powerful weapons and watching your enemies fall before you is immensely gratifying. The loot drops are frequent, and the anticipation of finding that rare and powerful item keeps you engaged and motivated to keep pushing forward.

The pet system in Torchlight 1 is an absolute stroke of genius. Having a loyal companion by your side, aiding you in battle and even going back to town to sell loot is not only convenient but also endearing. The ability to feed and transform your pet into different creatures adds an extra layer of depth and charm to the game.

Furthermore, the replayability factor is remarkable. With different difficulty levels and a plethora of side quests and secret areas to discover, Torchlight 1 offers countless hours of gameplay. Additionally, the inclusion of a robust modding community ensures that the game's lifespan is extended even further, allowing for an almost limitless variety of experiences.

Finally, I must mention the exceptional soundtrack that accompanies your adventures. The haunting melodies and epic compositions perfectly complement the gameplay, enhancing the overall atmosphere and immersing you in the world of Torchlight.

In conclusion, Torchlight 1 is a shining example of an action RPG done right. Its captivating visuals, addictive gameplay mechanics, rewarding loot system, and charming pet companions make it an absolute joy to play. If you're a fan of the genre or simply looking for an immersive and engaging gaming experience, Torchlight 1 is an absolute must-play. Don't miss out on this gem of a game!

Rating: ★★★★★

138159631.review:
Torchlight is an action role-playing game that reminds me a lot of the classic game Diablo II, which I used to play for hours on end. While the graphics didn't initially capture my attention, I found the game to be incredibly fun and addictive, with a deep level of character customization and an engaging loot system.

What I enjoyed most about Torchlight was the variety of character classes and skills available. Each of the three classes - the Destroyer, Alchemist, and Vanquisher - has their own unique skill tree, which allowed me to customize my character to suit my playstyle. I loved experimenting with different builds and seeing how they would fare in battle.

Another thing that stood out to me was the game's loot system. Finding rare and powerful gear was always exciting, and the pet system added an interesting twist. My pet could hold additional items, and I could even send it back to town to sell things while I continued adventuring.

While the game's graphics may not be the most impressive, they still do a good job of conveying the game's charming art style. The game's environments are detailed and varied, with each level offering new challenges and surprises. The boss fights are especially impressive, with each one requiring a unique strategy to defeat.

Overall, I had a great time playing Torchlight and would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a fun and addictive action RPG. The game may remind you of Diablo II, but it has its own unique charm and gameplay elements that make it stand out. Give it a try and see for yourself!

134221124.review:
UPDATE AFTER COMPLETION

No surprise that the last dozen levels were a slog, but nothing too excruciating, EXCEPT the final boss. I beat this on NORMAL at level 35, and the difficulty spikes get a little off during the last handful of levels. The final boss takes an absurdly long amount of time to beat. Maybe I could've grinding out more levels. 

The loot system gets pretty off near the end of the game as well. I was level 35, and some level 17 gear was better than the stuff I was finding on the bottom floors, which was still well below my level. I feel like most of my equipment was found by 2/3rds of the way through the game. In a 'loot' based game, that's just off. 

But still, game is beat, I stand by saying - "get it on a deep sale, and only if you love ARPGs." 


Before I talk about the game - 

Steam needs to make their recommendation system more nuanced. Instead of a simple 'yes' or 'no', maybe add 'yes, but only on sale', which is exactly where this game falls. 

I'd also say, deep sale, don't spend more than $5-$10 for this, and $10 is pushing it. 

Here's why - 

PROS: The music and general ambiance are really well done. It's got kind of a fairy tale feel, with a slight bit of spookiness to it, and the aged graphics aren't such an eyesore since they're cartoonish to begin with. The gameplay is standard ARPG. Controls are as you'd expect, and the game is more of a mellow out feel, and not really a stress on challenge. 

The thing is, this game is extremely basic, but charming. Now we'll get to the cons, cause there are a lot. 

CONS: 

So yes, this game is almost 15 years old, but feels even older. For a game that's primarily a loot driven style, they really made some questionable choices on the loot system, and then there are just some terrible mechanics. 

First, the gear doesn't vary much in visuals, which is a crux of these kinds of games. Get ready for your character to have the same look for every 10 or so levels. Superficial, yeah, but still, I like to see the incremental equipment growth of my character - from a new adventurer, wearing the basics, to more of a mixed bag, to eventually getting sets together, and finally to looking like a demigod. This transition is really slow here. 

The WORST offender is inventory management in general. You're given a very limited number of slots, and just about everything you find is 'unidentified'. Meaning you need to carry a ton of identify scrolls (another slot used), and use one on every item you find. It just feels like they dropped the ball on how that was supposed to work. You find the identify scrolls everywhere, so it's not an issue of managing them - which makes this even more puzzling. 

Also, the skill tree is really bare bones, so don't expect much noticeable growth, aside from just doing more damage and taking more hits. 

VERDICT: 

If you're an ARPG fan, and you like games with strong ambiance, this will probably entertain you for a while, but again, it's not really more than a $5 game. I think it's on sale all the time though, which is why I said 'yes' I would recommend. 

TORCHLIGHT II fixes almost every issue, and still has that same great feel, so if you're choosing between the two of them, there's no reason to choose the first. If you've played part 2, and are wondering if part 1 is worth it, then I'd say you'll probably appreciate it, but you'll really see how they improved the mechanics in the sequel.

130863440.review:
I haven't been quite so torn about how to assess a video game quite in the way that [b]Torchlight[/b] gives me an overwhelming desire to explain. On one hand, it isn't a terrible game; it's actually not bad at all. On the other hand, I feel I would likely have had more fun scraping my skull against concrete than I did playing [i]Torchlight[/i].

[i]Torchlight[/i] is, for all intents and purposes, a starter dungeon-crawler. Between its cartoon design aesthetic, its simplistic plot, its very rudimentary class/skill system, and the bombardment of mostly useless item drops, the game is, at its core, perfectly designed for somebody who hasn't played this style of game but wants a palatable experience that consists entirely of empty calories. Regardless of how you approach this title, it really doesn't leave much of a lasting impression outside of the fact that its plot is silly and the game-play is incredibly repetitive. That isn't really a bad thing though.

The entire story takes place in the titular town of [i]Torchlight[/i], or more accurately in a nonsensical sprawling dungeon beneath said titular town. You, the player, and your trusty pet are tasked with following a generic and forgettable NPC into some mines that lead to a plethora of seemingly unrelated but somehow interconnected dungeon floors to stop some sort of corruption from an otherwise generic bad guy whose name escapes me because it really isn't important. It's simple, very bland, and mostly there to give some sort of narration where none would have sufficed and still remained cohesive.

Now, my biggest complaint about this title is that it made 13 hours feel like it went on way longer than it had any right to. For such a relatively simple game, I felt as though the repetitive nature of the game turned into a slog about an hour in. Be that a result of faulty difficulty tweaking, the fact that most of the enemies are just reskinned versions of the same enemies you face on floors above, or that I don't have the stamina to repeatedly slap myself in the face with a keyboard to produce the same affect that could be had by not playing this title, I honestly couldn't tell you. Either way I'm dealt the dilemma of establishing whether I'd recommend this title, and for some twisted reason I feel like I should, if only to offer an easy entry into this particular game style. Perhaps I just need more sleep. Or perhaps Steam needs a neutral option instead of forcing me to choose whether or not I'd recommend a title.

123281969.review:
Las profundidades de Torchlight.

[h1]Lo mejor:[/h1] 

- Se trata de un ARPG de vista isométrica donde tendremos que recorrer los niveles subterráneos que hay debajo de un pueblo minero llamado Torchlight con el fin de descubrir que está pasando en sus profundidades y con unos cristales llamados Ember.
- Todo ocurre debajo de la tierra, así que tenemos como algunos escenarios minas, ruinas, ríos de lava, plataformas con puentes colgantes o una especie de palacio tétrico con decoración tipo drow de dungeons and dragons.
- Existen tres clases en el juego: Destructor, Alquimista y Conquistadora. Cada una de estas clases tiene sus propias habilidades que gastan maná y habilidades pasivas.
- Dependiendo de la clase tendremos pistolas, rifles, ballestas, arcos, hachas, bastones. También tenemos pociones de vida y de maná, así como pergaminos para volver al pueblo o pergaminos para identificar objetos.
- Existen pergaminos de hechizos con los que podemos equipar a nuestro personaje sin importar su clase. Existen hechizos ofensivos como una bola de fuego, defensivos como curación personal, hechizos de invocación como invocar esqueleto 1.  Se pueden encontrar versiones mejores de cada uno de estos hechizos.
- Lo especial que tienen estos hechizos es que una vez los aprendamos los tendremos de forma permanente (a no ser que queramos eliminarlo) y sólo gastaremos maná para usarlos. 
- Aparte de subir experiencia matando monstruos o completando misiones también tenemos una barra de Fama que se llena cuando matamos jefes. Al completarse la barra se pasa a un nuevo nivel de fama que nos dará un título y nos dará un punto de habilidad.
- Contamos con una mascota como compañero que tiene su propio inventario. Además, se le puede definir un comportamiento: agresivo, defensivo o pasivo y se le pueden dar algunos ítems para equiparla y darle hasta dos hechizos. También, la mascota puede agarrar los ítems del piso si así lo queremos y la podemos mandar a vender cosas.
- Si la mascota no tiene vida queda herida y huye lo que hará que no pelee ni podamos mandarla a ir a comprar, aunque luego se le regenera la vida lentamente.
- Hay objetos con ranuras para ponerles gemas, objetos de sets y legendarios. También se pueden encantar algunas armas para que tengan mas propiedades.
- Al vendedor de gemas se les puede comprar unos mapas que abren un portal que contienen escenarios con monstruos de un determinado nivel.
- Cuando salimos del juego y volvemos a entrar aparecemos donde estábamos, no en el pueblo o en algún checkpoint como en otros juegos.
- Se puede pescar y pasarle el pescado a nuestra mascota para que se convierta de forma temporal en otra criatura. 
- Hay diferentes monstruos como criaturas de Ember, hombres lagartos, arañas gigantes, demonios, etc.
- Los personajes se pueden equipar con un segundo set de armas.
- Los personajes que creemos puede compartir el alijo.
- Se puede seleccionar una dificultad.

[h1]Lo peor:[/h1] 

- El juego oficialmente está en inglés. Hay que bajarse un parche para ponerlo en español. Pero la traducción al español es floja: cómo van a poner "senial" en vez de "señal" o "extranio" en vez de "extraño". Se ve que la persona que tradujo no tenía la tecla ñ en el teclado, encima faltan acentos!! tenía un teclado inglés? :O
- El jefe final está muy desbalanceado. Le pusieron 50 millones de puntos de vida y encima no para de invocar esbirros. No esta equilibrado comparado con el resto del juego. Encima se me colgó dos veces en la final cuando nunca había tenido un problema en el juego y tuve casi que hacer todo de vuelta, digo casi porque el jefe no tenía toda la vida completa por suerte.
- Las misiones secundarias son todas las mismas, por ejemplo: te piden buscar a un determinado jefe para que lo mates, una determinada piedra de Ember o un determinado objeto de un escenario que te abren con un portal.
- Cuando la mascota regresa de vender siempre aparece un molesto cartel que nos avisa que la mascota regreso. Hacía falta poner el cartel? digo, no? porque que aparezca en medio de un combate es un poco molesto.
- Si tengo al personaje usando una pistola éste cuando agarra un escudo o un bastón de una mano lo equipa en la otra mano de forma automática. Esta mal. Eso lo quiero hacer yo de forma manual si quiero.
- A veces puede pasar que si volvemos a un escenario que hayamos limpiado éste se regenere y vuelvan a aparecer los monstruos. En cambio, otras veces no. En que quedamos?
- Por más que nuestra mascota tenga una poción en su inventario no la toma de forma automática cuando la necesita, no queda otra que darle la poción de forma manual para que la beba.
- Eso de que la tiradora o el guerrero puedan invocar esqueletos, zombies o lanzar bolas de fuego con ayuda de los pergaminos como si fueran magos como que no da.
- El hechizo "Invocar espada flameante" lo toma como hechizo ofensivo. Esta mal, en realidad es un hechizo de invocación.
- No hay un atributo para aumentar la vida o el maná. Directamente sube a medida que sube el personaje de nivel.
- El logro “Hat Trick” nos dice que ganemos el juego con las tres clases. Sin embargo, apenas me cree la clase que me faltaba para probar salto el logro :O
- Se repiten muchos diseños de mini-jefes, cambian el nombre, pero en apariencia son idénticos. 
- No aparecen los atributos de la mascota ni tampoco tiene habilidades para mejorar.
- El minimapa no pone nombres de personajes ni leyendas de los iconos.
- La mascota la verdad que la matan rápido, no sirve de mucho para pelear :D
- La traducción no está completa, hay partes que están en ingles todavía.
- No se le puede decir a la mascota que compre pociones o pergaminos.
- El Destructor en español tiene la voz de Loquendo hahaha
- El inventario del personaje y de la mascota es muy chico
- No se puede ordenar el inventario automáticamente.
- No se puede crear un personaje hardcore.
- No se pueden cambiar los controles.
- Poca variedad de enemigos.
- No tiene multijugador.

121525857.review:
For it's time, the game was pretty dope, but it didn't age well. I can't really recommend this thing to anyone (unless you want to get acquainted with it for its historic value.) 

I'll start with the negatives.

- Scaling.
The scaling in this game is busted. As you progress through levels and gear, so does the world of Torchlight. You move at the samey pace until you hit levels 20 and higher. You see, the damage scaling affects both physical and magical damage of the enemies. While it's easy to equip better gear and invest into your defense stat to mitigate the physical side of things, obtaining good magic resistance may prove to be extremely troublesome. Combined with the fact that Zealot mages cast a hitscan ability that cannot be dodged, you can see how frustrating progressing through later parts of the game and/or crypt can be. One way to gain resistance is gems, but gems suck.

- Gems
Gems are an upgrade system designed to help you out and allow you some creativity in customizing your gear. However, their droprates and upgrade system were designed poorly. Most of the time you pick up the worst kind of a gem and in order to upgrade it a tier you have to combine 2. You do it again to get to another tier, and to get a decent gem you need to spend a lot of time fishing the trader in the town and hoping that you get some on your journey. Furthermore, you get into this psychological trap where you don't want to use your gems on items because the items are kind of good and socketing them right now would be a waste. 
- Enchanting
Enchanting has this frustrating thing where it has a chance to disenchant your item. Let's say you get a nice set piece and you want to keep it for the set bonus. In order for the item not to fall off, you need to upgrade it through gems and enchanting. You might get struck by bad luck and instead of adding some effects to the item, you'll remove EVERY SINGLE ENCHANT from the item. And there's no way to control what enchantments you get. It's purely random. 
- Item sets
I've never obtained a full set armour in my 150 hours of play (I've had some playtime on a pirated copy before buying it here). It's just too random and wild. The only possible way is to put the items from the set into a shared stash and maybe, potentially, you can collect one though multiple playthroughs. 
- Some abilities feel unfinished 
Primary specs for each class feel awesome. Vanq is your designated ranged character, Destroyer is your melee character, Alchemist is your mage. Sounds good. Let's say you get bored with playing ranged Vanquisher, you want to try out the traps. Tough luck, they do not scale with anything in your kit, not your weapon DPS, not your stats. By investing points into those abilities you cripple your character, especially on harder difficulties. These abilities are just there. Same can be said about many abilities that characters have. This limits the replayability pretty much. 

However, there is that one broken thing in the game that can help you overcome any obstacle and that is inheritance. 

The way inheritance works in this game is that it allows you to pass one item to your next character once you finish the game. The thing is, once you hit level 2/3, the item gets its stats upgraded. If you have damage enchant on that item, the damage will increase, you get the idea. Long story short, on my Nth playthrough I upgraded my ring so much that the health digits on it went into the negatives and it would kill me every single time I tried to ressurect.

This is a good prototype of a better game, Torchlight 2. They fixed many of the issues the first game had in the sequel.

121406882.review:
[b]EDIT[/b]: Hit level 35 of the Shadow Vault on my Destroyer in VH non-hardcore and I've decided I won't be playing the game further. The constant threat of enemies pulling OHKO attacks out of nowhere, or entering a new level directly into a group of enemies that immediately attack you to the same effect due to poor randomization, turns the prospect of progressing further and preparing for HC into an RNG-fest that I'm simply not interested in wasting hundreds of hours on. I tried some rebalance mods that helped for a time, but they don't fix the randomization issues leading to stacked enemy attacks, the broken armor/block/resistances system that doesn't allow you to compensate in any way for the above, or the extremely punishing respawn system that basically ensures you'll either be grinding even more through the game's atrociously limited map pool (if you respawn back at town) or will never have enough gold to purchase anything but a few potions after a certain point (if you respawn at the beginning of the level).

[i]I have also read that Torchlight II has similar issues with enemy damage spikes and OHKOs, so I'll be skipping that game as well. I understand it's beloved by its community, and please understand if you're a fan that I wanted to like these games, but I am not the kind of player that can turn a blind eye to these sorts of flaws in a game. I like to complete my games 100% with all achievements to explore them to the fullest, and if a game is designed to punish you in unavoidable ways with the loss of dozens of hours of progress, or (in my estimation in the case of TL) is not playtested to ensure that players won't be destroyed in spite of doing everything correctly, then it's not worth the considerable investment of my time required to see everything it has to offer. Plain and simple.[/i]

[b]ORIGINAL REVIEW[/b]:
I'll write a more detailed review once I complete the game, but as of right now it's going to be a negative review, for a couple of reasons:

1) The game is *incredibly* poorly tuned. It plays like the developers were aiming for an easy casual take on Diablo, kind of like the old FATE series, and thus tuned the Normal difficulty setting to suit an easy-breezy casual game. Then, they messed around a bit with the numbers for the other difficulty settings, then shipped without actually playing them. The result is a game that is borderline unplayable as a melee character after a certain point on Very Hard difficulty, due to an insane number of OHKO's that can't be dodged. Add to that the fact that the armor system in the game is a simple flat damage reduction, making it practically useless compared to just stacking health and resistances, something the game never tells you until it's slamming you with OHKO attacks towards the end of Very Hard.

2) What makes the OHKO attacks towards the end even worse, is that the game's art style and particle effects (which cannot be easily adjusted without mods) make reading those attacks and moving away from them extremely hit and miss. Enemies will regularly be completely obscured by flashy effects, to the point that I have died more times than I can count to an enemy that I thought was dead, and which should have been dead if the hit detection next to terrain elements weren't utter garbage, hit me before the particle effect dissipated. It's as if the developers did not know how to handle the game being in 3D, designing effects that should be displayed flat against the ground to avoid clipping into terrain, but displaying them at the level of the characters' heads. For example, say you have an effect that displays a flat circle of electricity on the ground. If even a tiny corner of terrain would clip into that effect, instead of allowing that clipping to happen, the effect is displayed as if the whole thing were on top of the terrain, clipping into or completely obscuring your character and any enemies around him that aren't taller than him. Now multiply that by five, and add in the aforementioned OHKO enemies and maps that increasingly become strewn with more and more rubble in small areas populated by large mobs, and you will understand how crap the whole thing starts to feel.

3) The hit detection and control system is trash, and can't be defended by saying it was a product of its time in a world where games like Diablo and Titan Quest existed first. Left-click moves, but it's also your basic attack. But if an enemy is just out of reach of you as a melee character, and you click to move closer, there are times when the game will just register your click to move as a click to attack, without moving your character within range. This is especially an issue on stairs and around terrain, which become increasingly common as the game proceeds. Once again, it appears to be a product of the developers not knowing how to properly handle developing a game on a 3D plane. This issue is exacerbated greatly by the (uneditable) cursor being extremely small at high resolution, with a design that blends into the levels and characters, and which doesn't always highlight the enemy you're pointing at (again, due to wonkiness with the 3D engine).

In conclusion, there are so many incredible ARPG dungeon crawling games out there these days, from venerable classics like Diablo and Dungeon Siege, all the way up to modern games like Grim Dawn and Path of Exile. I know the idea of a bright, cartoony Diablo clone sounds like good grindy fun, but there is absolutely zero reason in the modern gaming landscape to go back to a game like Torchlight 1, especially not if you plan to 100% complete it or, heaven forbid, play on Hardcore mode. There are much better, more carefully crafted games out there by more skilled teams of developers that deserve your attention, so take off the nostalgia goggles and go look into one of them. You'll thank me later.

tl;dr: The developers of Torchlight did not playtest their game, and were not prepared to make a game of this type in a 3D engine. Go play something better instead.

118480300.review:
Boring and heavily repetitive. It does some interesting things -- the pet being able to sell loot is a very nice feature, and you have a choice of skill trees, but on the whole, it's painfully generic. I played through it on hard, and even there it's just a matter of scything your way through chaff on nearly-identical levels in batches of 3 between bosses and zone-theme changes. What few deaths I suffered were a matter of zoning out because of how ungodly boring it became.

The achievements, I think, tell a story of people getting sick of it. 72% of players entered the first dungeon. 65% beat the first boss. 49% beat the second boss. 34% beat the fourth. Only 18% of people beat the game.

The graphics, while dated, have a solid style, and as I said it changes the level theme dramatically after every boss. Equipment appears on your character. Nice to look at on the whole. I just don't find the good parts help it be any less of a boring grind.

I certainly wouldn't recommend it at full price. It regularly goes to 80% off and is bundled on other sites.

118418804.review:
[b][i]A quite enjoyable hack&slash, with a short "save the world" main story.[/i][/b]

[b]* 3 classes (fixed genders) with 3 pick & mix skill trees each:[/b]
- Destroyer (male): [i]Berserker, Titan, Spectral[/i]
- Vanquisher (female): [i]Marksman, Rogue, Arbiter[/i]
- Alchemist (male): [i]Arcane, Lore, Battle[/i]

[b]* In the character creation u choose a cat or a dog as your pet.[/b] 
You can later transmog your pet to the other choice if u wish.
Pets assist you in combat and they can also sell items to town, while u are in a dungeon.

[b]* 4 difficulties, from "Easy" to "Very Hard + Hardcore option.[/b] 
You can't change the difficulty once you create the character!

[b]* The main story takes place in a dungeon of 35 different levels/floors.[/b] 
After that you unlock another descending dungeon with limitless and randomized floors.
There are also some dungeons that you can visit via a quest portal or map.

[b]* Pleasant graphics but extremely repetitive. [/b] 
Also there is not a world map in this game! 
U just enter the available dungeons from a single town.

[b][i]Bottom line:[/i][/b]
Is this a good game? 
No, it is really nothing remarkable.
And it can get tedious because it feels so repetitive (especially visually).
Pick it up if u enjoy hack&slash games in general and u just want to play one more.

118337758.review:
While I have this game since 2012 I never managed to finish it (well at least beating the story main boss). Always gave up after a few floors because I've found the game boring. Well some weeks ago I restarted the game, saying now I finish it and I did.

Well yes it's boring. Extremely. Honestly it's incredibly dull and just generic. I know this is a simple ARPG but basically there is nothing engaging in this game at all.
- The loot is boring (even on higher floors 90% of the time you just get thrash greys) and the whole socket system is total bare bones. The armor and weapons themselves are not interesting either in terms of effect (no active spells at all).
- The floors and fights are almost always the same, almost like copy pasted. There is some sudden change of pace after floor 30 but it's too little too late.
- The skill tree while gives some space to try different builds it doesn't give you an official way of respeccing. Which means if you are locked into a "wrong build" and your loot RNG is bad you can end up with very weak weapons and generally low DPS for a long time.
- I finished the game with 3 active spells. One right click spell + one AOE spell + Haste. That's it. I didn't even need more which leads back to the boring aspect of the game.

I could go on but you see I wasn't impressed at all. It is a very basic ARPG which might be good on its own but with the all the things adding up... just becomes totally forgettable. No pull to do another play through with another character at all.

118058711.review:
What Diablo I could have been if Blizzard actually got around to it. Runic deserves your patronage. I wished that Torchlight 1 had more in the way of randomized quests like Diablo 1 did. This has proven to be a solid action RPG experience. I do regret that the RNG aspect has not been favorable. I find that when it comes to enchanting items, the chance of a failure has not been represented accurately. It starts off at 2% and increments by 2 points after each successful enchant. When you get to 10%, the chances of losing all enchantments is high.

To me, a 10% chance of failure is worth the risk IF INDEED it was a real 10%. That's still up to 90% of a chance disenchanting WON'T happen. I don't know why Runic didn't clarify what they really intended. It's safe to say that you want to stop improving your gear before 6-8 points and use Shrines of Enchantment instead. Thankfully the gambling aspect is much better than it was in the Diablo series, where you can see the prerequisites of an item upfront. That's important for hunting certain items.

Post-Ordrak difficulty can be stupid hard. I can't speak as a true hardcore because I wouldn't have the time and inclination to go for it, but certain enemies will kill you outright especially when they are positioned to your south in the isometric view(a flaw of the camera system). I have a preference for ARPGs to be less strategic, so there's some bias there. 

So in summary, the only two flaws are the RNG and the post-Ordrak difficulty tuning. It's probably not an obstacle for the true Stukovs, but if you're just wanting to enjoy a good ARPG it is a nice short-but-sweet affair. I give this a 10/10 with Angry Joe's trademarked excellence distinction.

116169951.review:
Where to begin?

Torchlight 1 is an ode of love to ARPG's, but probably just to Diablo 2 considering the year it was released. In every possible version of the multiverse, I would recommend this game for fans of the genre-- if they can read what I have to say next, and come to the conclusion that, despite the flaws, they would still take joy out of this experience.

This is not going to be the immersive, life-changing experience that Diablo 2 was. And this does not have nearly a fraction of the craft, care, and meticulous planning, balancing, and years of investment and development of Path of Exile.

This is the funny-looking yet genuinely sweet, light-hearted, and easy-going cousin in the otherwise broodingly dark ARPG genre.

The thing that might put off otherwise interested players about Torchlight 1 can be summarized in one word: [h1] Jank. [/h1]

Game mechanics, especially class skills, are opaque and under-explained. The pet companion constantly has frustratingly bad pathing around corners and staircases, causing many a back track. Packs of mobs and even bosses can be cheated down from range while you safely stay on the floor beneath (or above) them. Strange bugs exist, like when you use Ember Phase into a teleportation pad it can cause your character to enter a strange endless animation loop (pressing ESC got me out of it). 

The render distance is TERRIBLE  and there is no setting to alter it (I don't know if this is due to some automatic setting, however, considering I am playing the game on a POS laptop). The rendering distance causes you to be unaware of mobs until sometimes it's too late, and overall affects the flow of the game, telegraphing difficulty spikes, and planning out your next moves. 

Quest text for the repetitive side-quests consist of a rotating sample of descriptions, with only the name of the quest objective changing each time. A cost-cutting technique that surely reveals the smaller scope and budget of this game compared to other titles in the genre.

And whoever edited the quest text for this should have looked at a style guide. Commas, are, definitely, put, in, the, wrong, places, a lot, and used. where there should be. periods.

[h1] The Up-Shot [/h1]

I genuinely like this game. It's simple, addictive, and sticks to the failsafe ARPG formula. I can see myself replaying it for each different class and multiple different builds. 

The main narrative conceit is unintrusively simple. The writing for the main quest line isn't bad, and although some of the voice acting is a little cringey, the actor who voices Alric's journal entries isn't half bad. The necessary storytelling elements don't linger or get in the way-- this is a good thing. Gameplay first.

This is clearly a smaller budget project made by some people who probably loved the shit out of Diablo. It's not bad for what it is. In fact, it's charming, simple, and easy, with just enough depth to keep me wanting to play through some more. My Ember Strike build glass-cannon Alchemist is definitely starting to come together >=-)

114639903.review:
Torchlight is the very definition of mediocrity; it's about as flavourless as you can get when it comes to an action RPG built on the pedigree of the Diablo franchise.  It has a nice soundtrack reminiscent of the original Diablo and having a pet that can sell your items for you in town is neat, but as a game it simply isn't interesting enough to hold my attention.  There's nothing particularly wrong with it, it just feels uninspired and boring.  If you want Diablo-lite with cartoony graphics then you may enjoy it.

Functionally, it's similar to its inspiration.  You choose one of three classes and enter into a dungeon that goes further and further into the depths below the town.  The problem with Torchlight is that I can't shake the feeling that it's a low-budget kickstarter version of Diablo 1, without any of the charm or personality.  It has a very children's story book art style, which will either be a good or bad thing depending on who you are.  I find the artistic direction inoffensive but I don't particularly care for any of the playable character designs and I find the overall presentation uninspiring. One gripe I have with the gameplay is that ranged weapons seem to have some kind of artificial max range—which isn't particularly far I might add—where your shots just kind of disappear out of existence and don't have any effect on enemies, forcing you to move closer to them even though you can easily see them.  This makes ranged combat in the game feel unsatisfying and annoying.

Torchlight fits the role of a mindless Diablo-style action RPG but there are much better games in this genre to spend your time with.  I'd much rather go and play Diablo 1 or 2 again than play this; I can't help but feel like I'm playing a watered-down, diet version of a franchise that I love with an inferior artistic direction and none of the charm.

109661778.review:
Torchlight is a fantastic Dungeon-crawler ARPG created by the creative minds behind [i]Diablo series[/i]. In the world of Torchlight, there is a fine blend of Steampunk and Fantasy universe. We will see robots and magics come together beautifully. This game will deliver everything expected from a typical ARPG and even more in the best way it can.

Unfortunately, character creation is pretty limited. We can choose between three classes of Destroyer, Vanquisher, and Alchemist. Our character's name and choosing the pet's appearance (We can only choose between Dog and Cat in the first game!) are our last options in the character creation stage!

Beautiful cartoonish design of the world with a great soundtrack made by Matt Uelmen will make the Fact-pace, violent, and gore-ish combat humorously good! We have thirty-five floors to explore in the Main Campaign. If you were thirsty for more monster's blood after beating the Last boss there are some ways to calm that thirst! A new area will pop up in the city after slaying the last boss that contains floor after floor of randomly generated dungeons, lots of monsters, and lots of loots just for us! These dungeons aren't enough!? We can open a portal to a random dungeon and clear it out from monsters and loots.

Now will get to the best features of the game. Torchlight's inventory handling system is one of the best you can find on video games. 

You are overburdened with loots!? No problem! Your pet has a separate inventory just like yours. You can store the extra and unwanted items in there. Your pet's Inventory is overburdened too!? No problem! Send your pet to the city from any floor in the dungeon and your pet will come back with an empty Inventory and a pocket full of gold! 

You got overwhelmed in combat and you are on the verge of death!? Fear no more my friend! Set your pet's status to defensive and feed a fish to your pet and your loyal partner will defend you to the last breath with its superpowers! You don't want to cast a spell every time manually!? Just drop a Spell Scroll in your pet's Inventory and, done! Your pet will cast the spell automatically for you.

Torchlight is a fantastic ARPG that lacks Multiplayer but the Single-player experience is more than enough to have fun with this game! We can travel through dungeons and slay everything that blocks our ways and catch some fishes along with our loyal partner! We will loot every treasure that we can find down there and when we get too old we can leave the fate of the Torchlight world into our descendant's hands!

Happy Gaming

They are just different enough to be fun and interesting in their own right, and I find myself replaying this one again now, discovering for the first time that after you beat the main boss, it unlocks an infinite dungeon that you can delve down to find the best loot... and I only recently discovered a retirement system that lets you hand down special heirlooms to new characters as descendants of your original hero. 107170299.review:
Torchlight has dated mechanics and design, but it also holds up surprisingly well to modern Diablo-likes. One of the strengths of Torchlight is the ability to be modded. I encourage everyone who plays to take a look at mods online and download ones they enjoy. The ability to respec, new pets, new classes, or even complete overhauls are available. On my most recent playthrough, I played "Archanoth's Torchlight Overhaul", which is pretty faithful to the original experience but with a lot of quality of life improvements. Notably, it removes potion spam in favor of a heal on a cooldown. 

Despite this, modding has never fixed Torchlight's biggest weakness: lack of content. Once you beat the game, there's no reason to continue grinding, and you finish at a pitifully low level of 35 (out of 100).

106462052.review:
Torchlight is a hack n' slash dungeon crawler like classic Diablo, but it bears a lot more resemblance to Fate, which is not surprising since the now defunct Runic Games was formed by Travis Baldree. As such, Torchlight contains some differentiating mechanics like a selection of generic spells that any class can learn on top of their class specific skills and the player also has a pet by default that aids them in combat, can travel back to town to sell items and be transformed into more powerful forms by feeding them magical fish.
I like the Torchlight series because it feels like a classic hack n' slash, but generally more fast paced, and there's a lot more freedom when designing a character than with the usual rigid class system most ARPGs have, barring the lack of a respec system.
That being said, it's kind of hard to recommend Torchlight 1 when Torchlight 2 is superior in pretty much every single way. It's not like there's an overarching narrative to follow or something like that, there is a story linking both games, but it doesn't really matter to be honest. You wouldn't lose much by skipping this one in favor of the sequel.

RUNNINGSPEED1.2
RESPECMOD

i would consider the first 2 as mandatory.
Mod Folder is : C:\Users\YourUserName\AppData\Roaming\runic games\torchlight\mods,
you can get there by typing %appdata% in the windows searchbar.

i play with ATO V1.11 as well, but i don't like how much mana everything costs and i want chill gameplay, so i changed the mana cost of every skill. you can do that by editing the dat files  by opening them with notepad/editor inside

C:\Users\YourUserName\AppData\Roaming\runic games\torchlight\mods\ATO v1.11\media\skills\ClassYouWantToChange\SpellYouWantToChange

and change the value of <FLOAT>MANACOST:40 to the desired number of cost.

If you want an easy solution for the mana problem, navigate inside the Ato folder to the media folder. here you will find globals.dat. Change

 <FLOAT>MANA_RECHARGE_RATE:6 

the 6 here to a 12 and you will have fixed the problem as well.

Definatly recommend the game!

102249704.review:
[h1] 𝕋𝕙𝕖 𝕞𝕠𝕣𝕖 "𝕦𝕟𝕤𝕖𝕣𝕚𝕠𝕦𝕤" 𝔻𝕚𝕒𝕓𝕝𝕠. [/h1]

Remember Diablo 1? A game where you're thrown into a barren village and you're given the vital task of descending a cathedral in search for the source of evil that's spawning creatures of all kinds from the demonic realm to torment the poor villagers? Welcome to Torchlight, a village that's quite similar in distress.

The villagers in Torchlight, however, do not even care about the evil that lurks in the bottom of the mines... They are more concerned with mundane activities, such as the alchemist who literally says "Nobody cares about whatever's in the mine, all I want is this gem, find it for me and I'll reward you". Between the funny villagers, the funny interactions with them and a plot that you won't care about, Torchlight offers little variety in questing.

To emphasize, remember how back in Diablo you've had, fetch quests alongside some creepy, scary "open this portal at your own risk" type of quests? Like how you'd read a curse on a book and then a huge scary demon with a horrifying voice spawns out of nowhere, calling you a "FRESH MEAT" before you're compelled to run away as fast as you can? Well... in Torchlight, the quests are... quests! Fetch this gem, go into this portal to fetch the flowers... Slay this guy, slay this one, slay that one... At some point, Torchlight will feel very fleshed out and boring. I know it is quintessential for any RPG to have those, but come on... descending four levels for a gem and a small portion of XP isn't even worth it. 

Anyways, the game's mechanics are nice; you could also dual-wield as a mage and die in two hits, the game doesn't really care as far as your character's customization goes. There are three classes, a fighter, an archer (of sorts) and a mage. The level design keeps changing the further you descend into the mines, the voice acting is not mediocre, but not good either... The soundtrack is great and then there's... the fishing! Apart from the endless optional dungeon you get after defeating the main game's final boss, the fishing in this game is the most-dragged out, the most-boring activity you could be doing while playing... You've got an average of thirty seconds to a whole minute waiting for a circle to align with the fish mark for you to click it and get the fish... It's just annoying as hell, and for an achievement you have to do it a thousand times! Nope... gotta draw the line somewhere boys...

Torchlight is a 7.2/10 Diablo-clone. It doesn't take its plot seriously (and that's, to me, a good thing) and has a ton of memorable characters as well as a horrid fishing mechanic that, in my opinion, should be deleted from the other entries.

101736763.review:
This game is a solid meh. I recall playing this a lot back in the day, so I picked them all up on sale, hoping they'd be good. The game starts off okay, and is enjoyable, but progressed into a series of boring quests that are the same quest going down several floors lower in the dungeon. There is barely a story and what story there is is not interesting.

The progression in this game is not great. The game was manageable on hard until the last area of floors, where certain mobs one-shotted me randomly from a distance, even though I was appropriately leveled. The game just became blasting AOE at groups of mobs and making sure to kill this specific mob as soon as possible, so as not to get one-shotted. The final boss was a massive increase in health and took forever to down with the amount of adds that are spawned by the boss.

Since I finished it and it wasn't terrible, I will give it the ol' thumbs up, but I am fairly neutral about the experience. I got about 15 hours out of it, so based on hours it's worth the asking price, but if you factor in the experience, not so much. But on sale for only a few bucks, it's definitely worth it.

99116777.review:
I've played Diablo 3 some time ago. And it sucked that I can't get to the higher levels of difficulty to enjoy my game. It sucked ~10 hours on Expert out of me to even [i]get the chance[/i] to increase the difficulty. Also I found out that I love spending time on stats and skills management.
So, I remembered about my old Torchlight games. Man, I know this game from 2011 maybe? It's been a long time.  There you have all your pretty balanced difficulties (well, I played on Hard and it [i]was[/i] hard), the stats management and the skills tree. You are free to build your character whichever way you like. Unfortunately, I think, you can mess up your character by maximizing soon-to-be-useless skills. Consider this part of the gameplay experience - you might play a game maximizing the wrong stats and then you'll have to replay it. Some might like it, some might not. I did not have to replay the game, but I [i]was[/i] struggling on the last levels. Glad I had my minions to back me up. Man those little skeletons can put a lot of damage.

I think after ~10 years in the field this game still holds up.
Well, until you play Torchlight II. Yeah, as some reviewers point it out, I think Torchlight I is obsolete now. It loses on all counts: fewer classes, more boring loot and dungeons, generic enemy design. But only when you compare the two. For me, playing Torchlight I first made playing Torchlight II right after a so great experience I was just blown away by the improvements.

This game still allows for some mind-numbing clicking and loot grinding, but you may lose interest quickly. Pick a difficulty too easy - you'll breeze through the levels without caring about loot which is almost garbage. Pick too difficult - you'll struggle and since there's no good loot -- you'll find that your time is wasted.
Anyway, I enjoyed playing this game as Alchemist on Hard. It was pretty fun until the mid-game, then I just started playing in 30-60 min periods so it does not bore me.
The plot is pretty bland and boring. It's [i]just there[/i] - if you're into Torchlight universe and want to explore the first part before playing the second - just go to Wiki and read it there. You'll save yourself some time.

Be careful before you decide to play this game. It's pretty good for the time it came out.
Keep in mind - it's been made on low budget and in short time by very few people. It's like an ARPG-pilot for future greater game. Don't put high expectations on this one and you might enjoy it -- there's a good setting, art and music.

97630405.review:
So this is absolutely not a diablo-esque game. In any way. Unless you mean that both are RPGs set in a dungeon. But where the Diablo series was crafted with a lot of heart and planning this one is uninspired to the point that it feels like a mobile game. 

First - the good aspects. The ancestor gimick is kinda fun although the stat improvements that the "heirloom" item gets and the one skill point are absolutely insignificant. The pet traveling to town for sales is good, but given the mountains of trash drops without it I doubt people would 1) be piccking up items or 2) finishing the game altogether. 

Now for the bad. The classes are pretty much cookiecutter. You have your mage, your rogue (bow) and your melee basher. The skills don't synergize in any way so "builds" aren't a thing in this game. the skills are also quite uninspired as they are mostly just variations of a different damage type (fire, cold, magic, etc.) in a different area of effect (pbaoe, line, aoe, etc.). The items that drop are quite poor - on my lvl 100 char I never changed my weapon from lvl 42 simply because a better one never dropped. And it's not like I had found the motherlode either. The quest is generic and the story is uninspired. The movement is kinda floaty but worse yet the levels are mostly long narrow corridors so that eliminates any kind of skilled play or tactical planning. 

Some people say the difficulty "spikes" but I wouldn't classify it as such. It's more that you reach a point where normal mobs can't damage you but bosses can 1-shot you, so there's really no balance. and I don't mean 1-shot through some big dodgeable charge-up attack, I mean an insta-cast, insta-hit lighting for example. 

The worst offender by far is that the game just doesn't respect your time and it knows it has no replay value but will do anything to force you to play it longer. This is perfectly demonstrated in the achievements. some require you to finish 50 quests of a type that you get only 8 per full playthrough. Or you have to sell 10 000 junk items (your inventory holds a max of 21 items and some slots are reserved for scrolls, pots and quest items, so imagine how long that takes), or to catch 1000 fish - fishing being quite pointless and slow, with no upgrad eoptions to make it more viable. Or the fact that if you beat the game on the hardest difficulty on hardcore you do not get the achievements for the lower difficulties (as some far better games have done) so you have to replay it 4 full times just for those HC achievements. Let alone the softcore ones. Then there's one achievements that requires you to install 10 mods at the same time. 10! If that doesn't show that the developers knew their product and the experience they provide to be extremely poor I don't know what does. 

Anyway, if you are looking to waste some time I guess it's not among the worst games I've played but I certainly wouldn't expect any profound or even well-polished rpg experience.

97025846.review:
Greetings as I hope all is well! Below is my Steam Review for Torchlight, thanks for reading as I wish you well in all your gaming adventures...


STORY/LORE - 8/10

The story and lore to Torchlight is pretty similar to that of the famous Diablo franchise. Evil lurks under the town you’re in, citizens are worried about weird things happening, and you’re here to save the day. There are some decent characters and NPCs here, especially the heroes/classes you can choose from but there isn’t anything memorable like you’d find in Diablo.

Torchlight came out in 2009 and I remember playing it when it first came out and loved it instantly. It’s basically a cartoon version of Diablo, takes the same dungeon-crawling style of things, and puts its thumbprint on it. Best of all, you get to have a pet dog or cat by your side and get to name it as it helps you fight, store inventory, and even cast spells. Bonus points for that!

GAMEPLAY - 10/10

If you love endless levels in dungeons and enjoy plowing through waves and waves of enemies with bosses sprinkled in, Torchlight is the game for you. It’s a lot of fun as you max out your abilities, get upgraded weapons/armor, and work your way through the various levels and quests. Since there are a lot of different styles of play to use, the replayability is really nice if you want to see what each of the three characters brings to the table. 

Torchlight’s gameplay is fluid and doesn’t change the world or anything when it comes to hack and slash games but it’s a fun and immersive experience. This is easily the best feature of the game and again, copies that Diablo formula well as it definitely ranks up there as a beloved franchise that many gamers enjoyed when it first came out.

GRAPHICS - 9/10

Torchlight has cartoony graphics from start to finish and it all looks great. The level design does get a bit repetitive but even those look real nice too, especially the levels with lava. Considering this game came out so long ago, it still holds up to this very day.

SOUNDTRACK - 8/10

Again, Torchlight is a Diablo-clone, even the music in town sounds eerily similar to what it tries to copy. The levels you’ll go through do have their own unique sound to it which helps to mix things up but it’s pretty linear and nothing that truly stands out or is epic. Even when you encounter bosses, the music doesn’t change or anything. Towards the end of finishing up Torchlight, I muted the music since it does get repetitive and put my own music to chill out as I went through all the different levels.

MULTIPLAYER - N/A

There is no multiplayer at all in Torchlight, not even co-op. Since this came out in 2009 as a single-player campaign, it has stayed like that. There is a nice modding community for Torchlight and if you Google it, you’ll see that there are a ton of mods to use to add a bunch of new things to the game. 

No multiplayer option mods but at least you can download things like new boss packs, better user interfaces, and I even saw a mod that adds Jedi bosses into the game if you also love Star Wars. Yeah, lots of extra things to go through if mods are your thing to mix things up as you progress.

FINAL SCORE - 8/10

Overall, Torchlight is a very fun game and is one that I hold close to my heart. I remember playing this when it first came out in 2009 and instantly loved it. If you could believe it, my original character was still available to play and it completely shocked me that it was still saved and I was able to pick up and get right back into things. 

The different kinds of monsters, bosses, levels, weapons, and armor are all nice and unique. You can enjoy fishing if that’s your thing as well or play around with a very nice and balanced selection of abilities, spells, and fighting styles. If you want to melee, cast, use minions, dual-wield, etc., it’s all here and will give you a great time once you get to it. I would consider Torchlight one of those classic games many gamers remember fondly of. Especially if you love a good old fashioned hack and slash dungeon-crawling adventure that you can sink many hours into and have a blast in.

There's a big chunk of mods that fix a lot of "not very well though out decision" this game had, due to it's age, while the rest of it still provides a pretty fun gameplay loop.
Sadly there's not a whole lot of build diversity and some skills clearly outshine others, but raw gameplay is nice and loot matters - there's quite a bit of strong legendary items and they drop fairly often.
The retirement mechanic is pretty interesting, although slow in regards to skill points, since your skills are still locked behind level requirements, so it's only really usefull for passing down powerfull items as heirlooms.
Overall it's a very fun game and I'd recommend it to any fan of the hack'n'slash genre.

93538736.review:
[h1] Decent Diablo Clone [/h1]

[b] What I Liked [/b]

Enjoyable Diablo clone.  Nothing too memorable, but nothing too bad either.

[b] What I Did Not Like [/b]

Couldn't really hook me at the time, as Diablo II was still a better option.

[b] Why I Stopped Playing [/b]

Didn't hold my interest for long.

[b] Disclaimer [/b]

I have been a gamer for over 30 years.  I tend to play mostly PC games.  I also bounce around between games A LOT.  I may purchase a $60 game and play it for 2 hours or spend $10 on a game and spend 50 hours on it.  Even if I played a game a short time, it does not mean it is bad. If I do not have a complaint, then the game must be special!

Muy buen juego de rol de acción a lo hack and slash con toneladas de pillaje que efectuar. Muchas armas con sus caracteristicas peculiares, un montón de hechizos para aprender y usar. La ayuda de la mascota (que podemos trasformar también y hechizar. ¡¡Y que nos ahorra tiempo de mercadeo incluso, yendo a vender por nosotros!!) e invocados, es de gran ayuda. El sistema de lucha es bastante interesante y completo también. Visualmente atractivo, con un toque animado y estética medievo-steam-punk muy chula, con historia floja y prescindible. La progresión de dificultad y nivel sufre algún altibajo extraño; las mazmorras son entretenidas, con buen diseño y infinidad de enemigos bastante variados, aunque en un punto, parecen repetirse y se hace un poco aburrido.
Tieniendo en cuenta sus años, puedo decir que Torchlight ha envejecido  bien y sigue siendo un clásico digno de jugarse. Un gran debut para la saga!! (aunque su mejorado sucesor tiene más mérito) Si eres fan del género. No te decepcionará.

91146344.review:
A classic hack n slash dungeon crawler I've been putting on the back burner for years. If you are a Diablo fan, this game is a more "cartoonish" version of the series.  I'll do a small good/bad list of things that really caught my attention.

[h1]Good:[/h1]
- Tons of customization between class skills/abilities.  So many I would say I spent a good hour overall planning my builds.
- Endless combinations of stats on gear.  You can really stack unique traits for the build your aiming for.
- Wide range of different enemy types and zones you adventure through.
- Game art and music is relaxing and cozy.
- Very casual gameplay, easy to boot up and grind through dungeons without really needing to give it all your attention.

[h1]Bad:[/h1]
- Loot.  Any piece of gear that drops has to be "identified" with a scroll before you can see the stats.  This is completely pointless and took up a great bit of time.
- Inventory is very small.  However, you can move items over to your pet and then send it back to town to sell items for gold.  It helped, but I couldn't help but notice how long I spent identifying and moving items back and forth.
- No in-game re-spec option.  This has to be done via console command. (Does [u]not[/u] flag your character as a cheater, so shared loot-cache between characters is still available)
- Story was extremely short.  More than half of the game is spent grinding through endless floors of dungeons to lead you to small boss battle.  The final boss seemed to be the only fight in the game that actually felt like your character accomplished something.

[h1]Summary:[/h1]
I truly did enjoy my experience in the game and recommend any avid dungeon crawler fan to try it out.  This is a classic that has replay value as 3 different classes with a shared-loot cache between them.

Meh. Very bare-bones RPG. Good loot is very hard to come by and bad loot drops like crazy. There's also the need to use an identity scroll to uncover loot items, just why? It's extra work for no reason.

It was very tedious to complete this boring game.
