90274721.review:
Overall, this is a very fun little gem -- I personally prefer it over the sequel (T2). Not nearly as much depth as some of today's newer ARPGs, but it suits people who want a laid-back experience, plus it allows you to create some OP group-clearing builds if you put a little effort into understanding the spells and skills. You start the game just walking around, pointing and clicking and watching hp bars go down... but once you put together the right spells/skills/items (it takes a few hours at least to farm items and xp), you can sprint through each level and melt groups of enemies (similar to Diablo 3, I guess, but not as powerful). Or you can keep pointing and clicking if that is your jam.

The story is meh, and the sidequests aren't really worth doing unless you want achievements (or you have mods that boost the quest rewards -- this game has quite a few great mods out there). Also the endgame content is not super compelling... but for me the most fun part (and the one that rewards the most gold+items+xp) is sprinting through a level and melting groups of enemies and bosses. I have only done a full playthrough of the melee class (Destroyer) so it might be faster or slower on the ranged and mage classes, ymmv.

More specifically: For the Destroyer class, you want at least Haste+Dervish (spells for WAY faster move speed and attack/skill-casting speed) plus the Devastate skill (AOE melee attack). For items you look for crit chance and damage. So basically you run around at hihg speed, 1- or 2-shotting small groups of enemies and bursting down the tanky bosses. You will see 100k+ damage from crits when you have good equipment, like unique items with good gems and enchantments. Feels good.

90273379.review: I think the game is fun to play, and it relaxes me when I play.

90272487.review:
Pros:
*Graphics.
If you got tired with D2 grim dark graphics for some reason, Torchlight got you covered. The style is so friendly that even the darkest corner of a deepest dungeon with some vile abomination in it look like they'd been made for your 5 yo little niece.
*Pet.
Seems like a nice little additive compared to D1 when you have something to tank some damage before being hurt as some ranged glass cannon. If you don't rely on its tankiness, just use it as a courier to sell each of dozens white items you've looted and after a few minutes it will bring you some 2k gold so you could lose more when you die.
Cons:
*Pathfinding.
There's a single skeleton above you and you want to smash its skull. Well, just go around that corner and climb the staircase, then press on that skeleton with a LMB or a skill of your choice. If you're ranged, you may have some ways to kill it from underneath, but then you still have to find a way up there as the game can't comprehend it if you just command your character to go there or puck up some particular item.
It also applies to pets/summons/companions (Brink or what's his face) you may have**.  Meaning that you'll find them staring at walls when they try to get to some mob that is just around the corner awfully often. They also tend to pick the farthest one as a target so in a narrow corridors you may often watch you pet and a group of monsters just hugging in melee when monsters are trying to reach you and pet is trying to reach something on the other some of the corridor, none of them will try to switch and attack what's right near them.
**Tried a simmoner with imps and golems as skills and 2 different levels of skeletons+archers+sword as spells. Quite a lot of minions if you ask but they all are useless when they don't even try to attack and just line up against the wall. Similar to skeleton-necro in D2 against Duriel.
*Selling prices.
I get that they are often way lower than what a player would pay to buy the same item in many games but usually you end up eventually saving a sum up to a point when gold becomes obsolete. Well, maybe I am still to reach this but after 2 final bosses I seldom have more that a few thousands, the rest get flushed down to enchantment NPC just to make my inherited bow obsolete for like 50th time.
*Skills.
If you name a skills differently and make another animation it does not actually make it a different skill. So I've played a Vanquisher until the final campaign boss twice and have relatively low level Destroyer and summoner-alchemist. I read the skills and they don't make much difference. What I'm saying is there's no different mechanics to the skills, they may look a bit different but in a great scheme of things, it's just a melee slash/stomp or a ranged nuke/aoe/charge, all vanquisher traps fell essentially the same, despite dealing different types of damage or decreasing opponents' armor.
*Mods.
They are supposed to be a pro but... well... overall it seems like players can't make the game much less raw that it's been initially made.

89159374.review:
Torchlight. A game developed and published by Runic Games.

I am deeply invested in the ARPG genre, and constantly strive for a new game that would satiate my ever growing hunger in this field. Torchlight was one of those games. It had everything i was looking for, from game play style, to the visuals and even the atmospheric level design. Coming from titles such as Grim Dawn and Diablo 3 was definitely a learning curve and we will cover why down below.

[h1]Story 5/10[/h1]
Torchlight in no aspect reinvents the wheel, it only builds upon an already familiar and well loved mechanic, you run in, you kill things, you loot their gear and use that gear to kill bigger things and rinse and repeat until you are a God. It's story is no different, A relatively cliche story line that very barely covers a reason to delve into these caves and fight hordes of unrelenting horrors, but never the less you do and the story does begin to unfold the further down you go, but never really offers you anything groundbreaking at all. It's well written and the dialogue is entertaining but the depth and intrigue i look for in most RPG's as a whole now is almost completely lacking here.

[h1]Gameplay 5/10[/h1]
[b]+ Environments:[/b] One thing that has to be said about Torchlight is its development of environments. The world has been painstakingly designed to offer you a certain atmosphere with every step. You'll never feel as though the area is irrelevant or boring because of how unique each map is and can be as a whole.
[b]+ Characters:[/b] Much akin to the original Diablo there are only 3 classes here, Destroyer, Vanquisher and Alchemist (Essentially Warrior, Archer and Mage, for those of you keeping score). Now i know "Only 3 classes, that sounds like a negative?!" And it would be truthfully, but here it works and its works as well as you could hope for. Each of the 3 classes comes with their own set of trees to level up (3 Each) which really helps diversify the characters and gives a "unique" element to everyone's individual character.
[b]+/- Stats/Scaling:[/b] Torchlight neither nails it nor fails it the stat system, Although the levelling system in terms of stats works well from a purely mathematical standpoint, it doesn't really offer much in practice. 50 points into Strength will make you hit a lot harder, but the enemies on each floor are levelling with you, so the change is almost unnoticeable. Which is why i had to give it a mixed rating because although its done and allows you to "level" something, its almost completely useless as Armour and Weapons will be what define your damage, not your stats.
[b]- Movement:[/b] And here is where things get a little messy. The movement in this game despite being almost entirely mouse controlled is extremely clunky and often gets confusing to use. There are very limited amounts of movement skills that allow you traverse the maps easier but they vary vastly in usefulness.
[b]- Enemy Variations:[/b] In short, there aren't a lot and most just feel like a re-skinned version of the last. Very few enemies offer any sort of interesting ability or random effect that would spark some kind of "Oh that was different" remarks. But no, there really isn't a lot here and what is here is rather bland.
[b]- Loot Drops and Inventory:[/b] I chose to put both loot and inventory into the same negative column because they go hand in hand. The inventory space in this game is a joke, Most of the armour or weapons you find require identify scrolls to even become useful which also take up your already limited inventory, And then on top of that completely useless and under levelled gear will continue to drop for you well into 20 levels lower than you. Couple that with the fact that most of the armour you will find will be for the other 2 classes and not your own. It's definitely a frustrating experience..

[h1]Visuals 7/10[/h1]
In spite of its age, Torchlight actually has stayed relatively fresh and visually pleasing, It's far from a graphical phenom by any exaggeration but due to its cartoon style graphical quality and design it has aged extremely well. There was no significant drops in frames in the entire time i played, nor was there any minor or major graphical issues during this time either. The game has been designed extremely well and looks the part.

[h1]Audio 7/10[/h1]
Much akin to the visual segment of this review, the Audio has as well aged extremely well, Offering a crisp and delightful soundtrack perfectly scored for the game, and a set of minor although pleasing sound effects that will sound out as you complete your adventure here. Again there were no minor or major audio issues, and it remained crisp and clean the entire playthrough.

[h1]Overall 6/10 "Imperfect" [/h1]
Whilst not groundbreaking in any aspect at all, Torchlight is at its core fundamental, a very decent and well made game. Some of its mechanics are extremely outdated and are reminiscent almost entirely of Diablo 1. The world is interesting but almost devoid of any kind of history and lore, The characters and classes are well thought out and work well in the schematic of the game, but are limited by the clunky style of motion that it provides. Torchlight is a game i'd pick up on sale and not at full price, Because as interesting as it is, its missing a lot that i would expect by today's standards.

88533711.review:
[h1] Boring story. Play it on hard mode to have fun. [/h1]

I’m not the most experienced action RPG player. As far as I know, “Exiled Kingdoms” on mobile and, now, on PC is the only ARPG I’ve played, which I thoroughly enjoyed. After playing this, it made me search for more similar games, and Torchlight was one of the titles I’ve stumbled upon lists of ARPG suggestions. 

The gameplay has been often compared to the Diablo series, which I’ve only played once way back in the PS1 days. I barely remember ever descending into the dungeon so I can’t recall the gameplay. So I can’t make the comparison like what many reviewers say.

Torchlight is a straightforward hack-and-slash ARPG. You go into the dungeon, fight your way through a horde of monsters, descend further, and repeat.  

Perhaps I need to try more similar games to have better judgment when it comes to this genre. Because I think Torchlight can easily be repetitive. I’ve spent approximately three to four hours on my first run on normal mode. I reached floor 17, if I remember correctly, without ever dying. Then I got bored. I eventually lost interest and didn’t play it for two or three months.

Around February, I decided to give it another shot. I revisited my first character but I couldn’t remember what the story was anymore (I don’t like checking walkthroughs). So I eventually made a new one. But this time, I figured that I should try it on hard mode — to be a little more challenging. It was then that I got more invested and started to enjoy.

But if you want to play it for the story, there’s very little that this can offer. It’s lame and forgettable. So perhaps you can look elsewhere if you’re looking for a narrative-driven title.

Torchlight can be fun and exciting with all the killing of corrupted beasts, ghouls, monsters, and more. So if you’re up for that, then try it out. And if you’ve played other ARPG titles, play it on hard mode. You’ll have more fun. 

3/5

86941313.review:
Easily one of my favorite games from when I was a kid. 

My mom had a damn old lap top running Windows XP (I think) with broken audio and overheated fast enough to vaporize alcohol, and I still had a blast playing it. The first time I beat the final boss was one of my greatest gamer moments from the early 2010s. 

The graphics hold up astoundingly well with current gen stuff, as it has a simple, cartoonish art style. Very VERY performance friendly. 

The audio is pretty great. The wet explosions when a crit kills an enemy is always pleasant, and the music occasionally slaps harder than necessary. The voice acting is a little forced, but still enjoyable (Syl has the same voice actress as Ireleth from Skyrim)

Being a classic style dungeon crawler, the gameplay is "easy to learn, hard to master", with considerable build variety despite the limited classes and skill trees. Any class can use any weapon, meaning you can have a tank with an HP steal carbine that fires faster than a crackhead's heartbeat, or a magic man using a greatsword with every non physical damage type in the game, etc. The bottomless dungeon unlocks after completing the story dungeon (it's brutal for a laid-back player). The unique items are properly awesome, but not limited. (I acquired two "Double Axe"s shortly after getting back into the game. 

The story isn't overly grand. It's very straightforward and paced as fast as you play through it. Nothing to blow your mind, but it has some enjoyable peaks. 

9/10 (accounting for nostalgia)

If you want a more involved and complex ARPG, just jump straight into Torchlight II where those comparisons are more appropriate. 
Torchlight One is very basic, but gets the fundamentals of clicking on monsters until they die right and there is a lot of loot.

if you have played Diablo or one of its clones, this game should be familiar: kill and collect. Kill and collect. Kill and collect. Not much than this. You get the usual three classes (melee, ranged, magic). You get no customization other than choosing your class and your pet. Sure, there is a skill tree and specializations. But the subdivision is an illusion. All you get to choose is how you will kill the enemies. But as long as you don't expect nothing more than killing and collecting loot, the game can be mindlessly fun. 


conclusion
if you love Diablo you will probably like this game too. Even if you aren't a fan of Diablo, this game can be a nice casual loot game for a rainy day when you just don't want to think too much while you play.

79989328.review:
I'm kind of disappointed with this. On itself, this game is fine, but after checking out Torchlight 2, the flaws in this game become hard to ignore. My goal was to finish this game, so I could hardcore dive into TL2 knowing, that I've tried the previous installment. But by the end of my walkthrough, I was just mellow and waiting for the game to end. And the ending, oh boy...

OK, this sounds like an extremely bitter review, but listen me out. I rate games by the the way I feel after finishing them. If I have more positive memories than negative, I leave a positive review, and vise versa. That being said, you'll love this game if you love Diablo. The gameplay's very similar and even the soundtrack is made by Matt Uelmen, the person behind Diablo II's soundtrack! My main gripe with this whole experience is the lack of consistency throughout the campaign and it's difficulty.

I'm not a person who loves to grind for XP or gold in similar videogames, but I still spend a considerable amount of time exploring bonus dungeons or completing side quests, if they seem to benefit me and look fun. But every single side mission (except one in particular) just follows the same path as your main quest does, so you never even have to go off the beaten track to complete them, which honestly seemed very lazy to me. The exception was the portal side quest, which only teleported you to a random dungeon to acquire some artifact. What's the difference between this one and the other ones? There isn't any. You just appear on a dungeon which has a set amount of floors, so you don't actually progress in the storyline whilst playing it.

And what is up with the huge deviation between enemy strength in this game? Every single boss (except Ordrak, but that deserves a seperate segment on its own) was ridiculously easy to beat, whilst the general monsters in the dungeon give you so much more trouble. Not to mention the difficulty gaps on the bonus portal scrolls you can teleport into, which have enemies far higher than your level and supply no worthwhile rewards after beating them. Well, sometimes you find a 'unique' weapon, which, oddly enough, doesn't even feel unique by the end of the game, for all of your current equipment feels so much stronger.

**Noted, I did play this game on hard difficulty. But this final boss is INEXCUSABLE, not even on the difficulty I've been playing at.

So, you've come this far, you've reached the final floor of the dungeon to find Ordrak - this collosal creature of dark ember energy or... whatever. Keep in mind, this whole game has been leading up to this battle, so you imagine this'll be pretty epic, right? Well, it's not. It's actually... absurdly stupid. As every previous boss was a piece of cake, taking only 3-6 minutes to beat, Ordrak is a BEHEMOTH OF DAMAGE ABSORPTION. I have NO IDEA who's idea was it to make Ordrak so time consuming and such a pain to beat, but dang, they've done their job. Not to mention the array of maybe 3 or 4 moves that he had, which made him so boring to fight and, by the end of it, I harddddcoooore just cheese'd him. I spent atleast half an hour blasting this crystal cunt with everything I had, respawning for maybe 5-6 times until I finally downed him. I bet he accumulated all of the damage I've delt to all the previous bosses, times 3, 'cause this was a TASK, like HOLY MOLEY. And finally, what's my reward?!

Some chick pops out from the portal to say 'thanks'.

What.

The.

Fuck.

My biggest issue with any type of isometric RPG or "diablo clone" is that they just have a really hard time being anything other than a giant labyrinth with hundreds of monsters that ultimately serve no purpose other than just being there. Aside from those specific gripes that I have with the genre itself this game is very fun if only for a few hours and I personally feel there is very little reason to actually finish it. At $15 or your regional equivalent, you can do a lot worse and it's simple but more cartoonish art style helps it still hold up graphically. I wish the fish system had more going on and that fish would just drop randomly it would have made me more inclined to use them. I mostly played the entire game without ever using a fish. The final boss seemed very spongey which makes me believe it was supposed to be a brick wall to push the player to do more random dungeon portal maps. 79095015.review:
Don't let my playtime fool you; I've played countless hours on a non-Steam copy of the game I purchased at a book store years back, as well as the Xbox 360 version of the game.  I can wholeheartedly recommend this game to fans of ARPGs, both casual and serious, both new and veterans. This game serves as an excellent starting of point for new fans with how system is very simplified, but also as a good way to scratch any ARPG itches for veterans looking for something post Diablo 3 with how flexible the difficulty system is and the learning curve in it. Though there may not be a workshop, this game does in fact support mods, up to 10 at a time, in fact. And just like Torchlight 2, mods really do breathe a lot of life into this game in areas where it really needed it, such as class expansion and enemy variation. 

The game is far from perfect by any means, however, as the content in game is rather lacking compared to other ARPGs on the market, especially compared to its sequel. You only have three classes, the pet system doesn't really have a lot of depth to it outside of having them sell things in town, the quest and dungeon system is very FATE-esque, meaning you'll really only be going through the same dungeon, but this time, you might have to kill a certain enemy or find something. Even with the Shadow Vault, the endless dungeon unlocked after the main campaign, you're just doing more of the same, this time in an endless dungeon and with the idea of perhaps retiring your hero and doing a New Game with the descendant.

However, with all that being said? I still 100% recommend this game, especially since this game, like Torchlight 2, go on killer deals nigh constantly. The game, despite being over a decade old, looks gorgeous in a lot of areas, and plays wonderfully. Scratches the Diablo itch nicely, and it is a very light weight package, and can run on almost any computer. My horrible HP Pavillion All-in-One that I bought off of HSN back in middle school can run this game perfect, which only speaks to its optimization. I'll miss Runic Games, and so I say purchase this game in their honor.

77470544.review:
Torchlight is technically excellent but unexciting. You shouldn't really take this game seriously, if you want a worthwhile hard core experience skip this entry and go with its sequel Torchlight 2. The sequel is better in every way. 

Game mechanics are a bit wonky thanks to questionable design decisions. Such as a cheap enchanter that allows a high amount of repeated use at the risk of voiding all the stats on the item. Good luck min-maxing that mechanic. The game doesn't have much viable build diversity for higher difficulties. Loot property ranges are so wide that you'll have for example two Uniques of the same name drop with completely different stats and rolls. As a result it feels like there's not much point farming for specific gear. Gear isn't very appealing and that's a shame for a dungeon crawler. The final nail in the coffin is that you can't respec, you can't even undo a misclick so you really should be careful when you're choosing your skills! Luckily it's not all bad, or I wouldn't have recommended this game now would I?

Thankfully the community has come in to lift the game out of the hole it had dug for itself. There are tons of mods, from mods that completely change the gear that drops, mods that add new vendors and even those that add completely new features to the game. If you take the time to mix and match you'll be able to craft a version of this game that's most enjoyable to you. This awesome mod support is what makes Torchlight great, despite its shortcomings.

76414451.review:
TL;DR Its not awful but there are much better options for hack'n'slash titles out there. Even if you are a Torchlight II fan i recommend looking elsewhere.

I had some fun with this game, no doubt. But if I weren't bored and stuck indoors (and a stubborn completionist) I probably would not have finished it. It's a standard Diablo clone. Made, as I understand, by some of the Diablo 2 dev's, it stands as a sort of "Diablo 2.5". Which would be awesome, if it weren't so repetitive. 

Pros:
Good art. There are modern AAA games with 10x the pixels and 100x the polys that don't look this good. The tech level of the game is atrocious but the devs had the talent to make it look better than it has any right to.
Traditional hack'n'slash gameplay is fun for a while. Lots of content.
Tons of spells, huge skill trees, and a massive arsenal of equipment for each of the playable classes offer many options for how you want to play.
There is some good level design in places. Puzzles, traps, ambushes. Even some of the optional side dungeons had interesting bits.
Some upgrades over Diablo 2 like pets, which can either fight or ferry unwanted items to town for you.

Cons:
Too few enemy types, and too many different enemies that do the same thing. This negates the potential offered by the character build variety.
Awful enemy AI.
Godawful tech. Engine and graphics fidelity were outdated when it launched in 2009. It looks 8-10 years older. Units and actions actually seem to freeze in time if you move more than a screen or so away.
Both the individual areas and the game itself run on too long. Everything is too repetitive. There are some good elements of level design and fun surprises but they are little nuggets in a sea of filler.
Story is bland, vague, fantasy drivel. But you didn't come here for the story anyway.
Like the Diablo series, it is very easy to ruin a character by poor skill and stat point allocation. Most of the spells in your skill tree become lackluster after 5 levels, and useless after 10. Only put one skill point per unlock until you know what you are doing. Most should be saved until you understand late game scalings. 
Game is too easy. Play on minimum of Hard or you will be bored.

Overall, Torchlight satisfied my desire for some mindless low-stress grinding and compulsive looting. I have to acknowledge, however, that this game hasn't aged well. I cannot in any good conscience recommend it to anyone knowing that there are much better modern hack'n'slash titles available at a similar price point.

Torchlight is a fun game, unfortunately Perfect World bought Runic Games, then closed it a few months after the release of Hob.  There will never be updates or feedback to this publisher.  The reason wasn't because they did bad games, it was because Perfect World has been buying up all kinds of Indie publishers and then closing them with the excuse to focus on "games as a service" as in online games like Perfect World International. Then why buy up the studios that focus on individual offline gameplay? To kill competition.  Torchlight and Hob are great games. If you don't mind there never again being patches or sequels or anything else added to it, they are fun games as is, and great if you just want to experience them.

TL;DR
Runic Games was closed just after Hob was released (by a larger company.) Don't buy if you are looking for a perfect game. Only buy realizing it is AS-IS and the people who made it are getting 0% of the profits.

73295715.review:
The beginning was promising. Many various skills, many methods of upgrading weapons and - what I liked the most - pets and summons. In addition to normal experience, the game has system of "fame" - it increases each time we beats a huge monster and new fame levels give additional skill points. Fight mechanic wasn't perfect (it's too easy to click near the monster instead of on it, which is a bit annoying), but it wasn't bad either.

The game was so easy that I quickly switched to hard, because normal difficulty was too simple to beat (it was really like "I click attack and monsters die"). I faced the consequences later.

For long time I was beating one dungeon after another, doing quests. Here is the first problem: each floor was bigger than previous one. So big that after some time it started to take more than half an hour per floor, and usually there are 4 floors per dungeon part. This wouldn't be so bad if fights were interesting, but... well, fights are just one monster swarm after another. There are only few monster kinds per dungeon, so for all four floors I just beat almost identical groups, which becomes boring after some time. But I still played - at least, I wanted to finish the main story (this one isn't great, but not that awful too).

And then, around level 30, I faced consequencees of choosing hard. Difficulty suddenly increased from "not so easy, but fair" to "*** monsters that kill me in a blink me before I even see where they are". There was no tactic other than going very slowly to lure monsters one after another - which made already long levels even longer to play. In addition, to not lose experience, after each death I had to come back to the floor entrance and go through long, long corridors back to the place I previously died. Which is extremly pointless, because monsters don't respawn, so it's just a two-minute walk through empty corridors. Not so funny if you die five times on one floor.

Maybe there are hardcore players that may manage to deal with constant swarms of monsters with ease. Maybe there are better character builds than mine. But at some point, I started to be more annoyed by this game than had fun.

Some people say that Torchlight II is better - maybe, didn't try it. First game, unfortunately, has too many problems with game flow. That's why I can't recommend it to anyone else than hardcore fans.

72371050.review:
★ I wrote this review to help you decide whether you can get [b] YOUR MONEY'S & TIME'S WORTH [/b] from this game.

[h1] TL;DR [/h1]
★ I only recommend buying this game when it’s on sale or included in a bundle. If you like Torchlight series in general i'd recommend getting Torchlight 2. It's way better and you won't miss much if you skip this one.

[h1] SUMMARY [/h1]
★ Good people decided to settle down near a mine that contains a rare and powerful ore and now they are in danger because bad creatures also want that ore. You get to play as a warrior, an archer (can also equip guns) or a mage. The story takes place in a 35 floor dungeon and in the form of voiced text. After completing the story you'll unlock an endless dungeon which is the endgame. Almost all of the gameplay involves clearing dungeons. There's a horse with whom you can engage in philosophical conversations. Your inventory is small,  junk loot is a lot and some enemies have huge damage spikes. You have a pet that's actually useful. You can fish, feed that fish to your pet and watch it transform into a spider. There are fame and character retirement systems. Most difficulty options are easy but there's a hardcore mode which makes death permanent. The environment is randomly generated, interactable but lacks puzzles. Visuals are cartoonish. Soundtracks are few. The game is highly moddable but not multiplayer.
★ More reviews like this: https://steamcommunity.com/groups/usefulreviews

[h1] STORY (Short) [/h1]
★ A small enclave was founded near a mine full of veines of a rare and powerful ore and it's in danger because all types of wicked creatures wish to secure this ore for themselves. These creatures come from the levels beneath the town. These levels make up the main dungeon and you need to clear these levels to progress the story.
♦ The story and dialogues take place in the form of voiced text.
♦ There are three characters (warrior, archer and mage) you can choose, each having their own ending.
★ After finishing the story once (with any character) a new endless dungeon will be opened for you to explore and three NPCs will start giving random quests which require you to progress in this dungeon. You can grind here forever.

[h1] GAMEPLAY (Simple and follows common mechanics)[/h1]
★ Remember that horse i was talking about? [spoiler]Jokes aside, he is actually an important part of the game if you are a completionist.[/spoiler] 
★ Almost all of the gameplay takes place in dungeons. Torchlight isn't open world but it isn't exactly linear either.
★ There's no multiplayer.
★ Bosses don't respawn.
★ Your magic resistances scale poorly. You take way too much elemental damage.
★ The main dungeon consists of 8 zones split amongst 35 floors.
★ There is a huge difficulty spike in the final boss battle. This is also true for some other enemies.
★ You can retire your character when it reaches level 30. A retired character passes down an improved version of an item you own and changes its name so that it includes your character's name. Retired characters become unusable.
♦ Nothing unique about the leveling system and it's capped at 100.
★ There's a fame system. Completing quests, killing champions (bigger and more difficult monsters with fancy titles and stuff) and bosses gives you fame. Advancing a tier gives a skill point and a fancy title. The fame cap is 55.
★ Most difficulty options are easier than they should be but there's a hardcore mode which makes death permanent.
♦ You have a pet that can equip spells and items. It flees when its hp depletes and it doesn't have the brightest AI.
♦ Each character has 3 skill trees, each promoting a slightly different playstyle. 
♦ You have a stash for your character and a shared stash.
♦ The distance at which enemies are rendered is kind of short.
♦ Hitting enemies isn't always easy. Sometimes you have to be at their level and/or be close to them.
★ Your inventory isn't really big and you'll come across lots of junk loot.
♦ There are way points at the end of each zone.
♦ You can send your pet to town to sell its inventory contents. This process takes less than a minute.
♦ The town area is where you'll be spending time when you are not in a dungeon. This place hosts a variety of NPCs some of which fulfil different purposes (merchant, quest giver etc.). There's even a shady guy that feeds your gambling habbits by selling you unidentified items for an above average price.
♦ You receive a short piece of story the first time you enter a zone.
♦ There are fishing spots in game. Some fish give your character a bonus, some transform your pet into another animal either temporarily or permanently.
♦ Items aren't restricted to one character but require certain attributes and level to be equipable.
♦ Socket-gem mechanics exist.
♦ There are a good variety of enemies and weapons.

[h1] ENVIRONMENT (Randomly generated, not huge, has a few puzzles and exploration is somewhat rewarded) [/h1]
★ Each of the 8 zones have a distinct visual style (the 8th zone is only for the final boss battle).
★ There are many interactable objects scattered across the floors. Some set off traps whereas some give loot.
♦ Although you cycle through the same 7 zones in endgame, them being randomly generated make the map feel less repetitive (but it still feels so).
♦ Most places lack puzzles.
♦ There are hidden areas that contain good loot.

[h1] VISUALS (Cartoonish) [/h1]

[h1] SOUNDTRACK (Not many but good) [/h1]

[h1] ACHIEVEMENTS (Some of them are time consuming)[/h1]

[h1] TECHNICAL (Developer console and save location)[/h1]
♦ There is a developer console which you can use to alter the game (check Torchlight Fandom for more info). There are a variety of commands you can activate 
but some of them flag your current character as "cheater" when activated. That character will loose access to the shared stash.
★[b] Save files [/b] are located in: [b] %appdata%\Roaming\runic games\torchlight\save [/b] (I believe it's always a good idea to backup your save files.)
♦ The game doesn't suffer from any form of bad optimization. (At least in my case.)

[h1] MODS AND SUCH (Numerous mods and a game editor)[/h1]
★ There are numerous mods you can try on [b]Torchlight Fansite[/b].
♦ The game comes with a game editor called [b]TorchEd[/b]. This appears as a free download in your library once you get the game. This is the very same editor the developers used.

72242232.review: If you liked Diablo, you will like this one. Really nice and fun game.

72204970.review:
Finished up Torchlight with 26hrs total gameplay. This includes one run on a vanquisher to about level 15 which was somehow deleted by my nephew when he played for a few hours on an alchemist. I then started another vanquisher from scratch and rushed through the story and finished up at lvl 29. For the age of this game(2009), it is solid. I believe Torchlight is classified as an Action RPG Dungeon Crawling Hack and Slash. I'd say this is accurate. If you're craving a story rich dungeon crawl, this isn't the one for you. If you're wanting to hop on a game, jump into a dungeon, and smash random baddies faces in....then this is for you. I Love torchlight because I can hop on and run a few levels and then walk away. As someone who has a ridiculous backlog of games with little time to play them, its nice to have a little dungeon crawling action without committing too much time.  

I burned through the story on normal mode rather quickly and beat the main boss at level 29.  I didn't die once until the last 3 levels and then proceeded to get my face smashed repeatedly by the final boss. I only did the fame quests and skipped all other side quests. The level cap is 100, which may explain the difficulty of the final boss. I did finally best him though.

There is a lot to like with torchlight. There are three playable classes. Alchemist(mage), Destroyer(warrior), and Vanquisher(ranger). Simple point and click movement with your left mouse button, which is also a basic attack when targeting an enemy. Your right mouse button is an alternate attack(assigned by you). You can assign hot keys to 1-9 for attacks, spells, and potions. Every class gets three different skill trees to assign your points as you level. You get points to put into your base stats as you climb the ranks as well. I didn't play any other classes except the vanquisher, but I thoroughly enjoyed the ranged attacks. You also get a pet(cat or dog) that not only assists you in battles, but also has inventory space. You can load them down with junk gear and stuff you don't want and send them to town to sell while you continue your journey. Each character get a chest of their own in town and one shared chest that can be accessed by any player on your account. The graphics are a little dated and a bit cartoonish, but it didn't really take away from the gameplay for me. I think you could probably run through the story on normal in a weekend if you kept at it. Overall I give it a 7/10 and would certainly recommend it.

70864516.review:
Fun but pretty basic Diablo-clone. The game was made really quickly by the developers and it can be told. Gameplay is pretty simple, there are three classes and they share a lot of the same passives. The classes are Destroyer (melee), Vanquisher (ranged / trapper) and Alchemist (caster / summoner) There are few abilities for each class, a Vanquisher will likely use either Ricochet or Explosive Shot as they're the only really good abilities. There's a Hardcore mode and several difficulties: Easy, Normal, Hard, Very Hard. In practice this is really: Trivial, Easy, Normal, Hard. If you're experienced with Diablo-clones then I'd recommend playing at a min Hard. You'll likely be really bored playing the other difficulties otherwise. There is also a hardcore mode.

A unique element of the game is that you have a pet. This can support you (mostly in lower difficulties) and acts as loot mule. The graphics are a bit cartoony.  Whether this is a plus or negative depends on the individual. A bigger issue is that magic damage against you has really poor scaling. Torchlight's elemental reductions remove only a fraction of the huge damage you take late in the game which is a really annoyance.

There's the main story dungeon which has 35 floors with one final meat shield boss and The Shadow Vault, a secondary dungeon that is unlocked after you beat the game once (including on fresh characters) It's an endless dungeon that goes for ever. It's full of random enemies and hero monsters. Grindy and a little boring.

Bosses don't respawn so boss farming isn't a thing. Primarily you'll farm gold and use that to enchant your gear to potentially broken levels. This is offset by the fact that it can randomly wipe it's stats instead. This was better balanced in the sequel by making it less powerful while not wiping your item. Beating the game lets you retire that character and 'heirloom' an item to give it a big buff for your next character.

I enjoyed playing through the story dungeon with the characters. It doesn't take too long to complete the achievements. It doesn't have much long term draw compared to other games. There is just enough build diversity or interesting content compared to other games in the genre like Titan Quest, Path of Exile, etc. It's still worth playing but I'd suggest waiting for a sale first.

70372276.review:
The game is good for the time it was released, but unfortunately it doesn't stand up to similar games anymore. If you enjoy diablo-likes, are interested in Torchlight 2, and really want to see where the series started, then check this one out. But if you just want a good diablo-like, then your money might be better spent on a more modern game, as they're pretty much all better than this one.

There's a lot to like in this game, from being able to have a pet companion, to the interesting magic, fishing and endless dungeon post-game. The gameplay doesn't feel as good as it's newer counterpart as it doesn't feel as responsive, but it does the job just fine. If you've never played a diablo style game previously, it's a good way to get into these types of games. It's not too difficult, the game is very straightforward, and your pet makes the trip a bit easier on inventory management.

If I wasn't reviewing this game in 2020, I would 100% recommend it to all. But if you are looking for a great diablo-like game now, try looking elsewhere as there is a lot of them around now, and they're all better than the original torchlight. If you're on a budget and want a decent experience, then Torchlight won't let you down either. It's still a good time!

This is the first action RPG I cannot recommend. Diablo 1-3, Titan Quest, Grim Dawn, Path of Exile are all better. Some of the weaknesses here:

- very limited inventory and item set (you don't get that "I need a new shield/sword/armor" feeling)
- skill tree is rather simple (not as many game changing skills as in other games)
- poor graphics (even for 2010 when it came out)
- item pick-ups (everything is stacked, sometimes impossible to pick up what you want without also picking up trash)
- the universe is not very enticing (dark fantasy as in Diablo/PoE, mythicism as in Titan Question, or steam punk as in Grim Dawn were all nicer and more immersive worlds)
- dismal "story" if you can call it that
- story-telling (text of cryptic diaries, nobody cares)

Overall, playing this game feels more like work than fun, and there is nothing that it does better, or at least as good, as the above alternatives.

69423794.review:
[i]TL;DR: A boring, basic RPG that didn't entrance me in the slightest. If you like going deeper down a dungeon with your brain turned off, this is the game for you.[/i]

I wasn't sure what I expected, but wasn't this. I know the game has been well received for the most part and did well enough to even produce a sequel, but it really didn't work for me. It's been one of the most boring RPGs I've ever had the displeasure of playing. 

Let's start with the graphics. They're nothing to write home about. The bodily proportions of all living creatures aren't exactly charming in my opinion and the textures are bland. The visual effects of special attacks and the like aren't anything special either. Visually, the game is mediocre at best. The soundtrack was forgettable as well.

But let's move on to the game mechanics. The gameplay itself is hindered by the extremely simple combat system. There are three classes, each with three upgrade paths for their skills. That seems promising, right? Well, in the end it doesn't really matter what you choose, at least not on standard difficulty. There are passive upgrades to simply increase your damage in one way or another (boring!) and upgrades that give you new, cool abilities (yes!). Unfortunately, you can only use one active ability at a time. The combat is mostly just left-clicking and right-clicking things with very little tactics involved.

I have to admit, however, that the pets and fishing mini-game are a nice touch.


Overall, I would not recommend this game unless you're a really big fan of the genre.

68381122.review:
First impressions (at 0.8 hours of play time):
This game is Diablo 1, with legally distinct differences. The town music feels like the Tristram music. The mines ARE the cathedral. There are more characters to interact with. You have a pet that fights and carries stuff. Your mana regenerates. Town portal is there. It feels like an updated Diablo in every way, so far. It also feels pretty generic and straightforward. If the other reviews are accurate, I feel that I probably will play this one or two more times for about an hour each.

If you can get this game super-cheap, it might be worth it. If not, I'd say pass. It's all been done. I, personally, don't have the wasting-time to burn on something like this. If you're looking for an interesting game with something different to offer, I recommend Receiver. Note that there are virtually no similarities between that game and Torchlight, which is the point.

68371899.review:
Torchlight:

ARPG /hack ‘n slash made by some of the guys behind the wonderful Diablo, Diablo 2 and the Fate games.


What I liked about it:

-3 classes just like the first diablo (similar : warrior, archer, and mage type classes)
-Skills are great fun and cool looking
-Spells you can equip on your pet
-Pet system just like in the Fate games (your pet can be send to town to sell your excessive loot).
-The music feels different but I felt the Diablo vibe behind it
-Art style (graphic) even though more cartoony, it mixed well with the general setting of the game
-Story is similar to the one from Diablo 1.
-Replayability and many different possible builds for the classes to experience with. 
-the fact that you can use bows,swords and guns is an interesting mix
-fast and nervous gameplay (need to react fast) which makes it interesting and challenging
-different enemy types
-some surroundings/environnement were nice, some dwarven halls reminded me of Lords of the Ring (dwarf  mines).


What i didn’t like about it:

-They decided to give the game perspective so you will often go up or down stairs, but enemies will attack and rush you from afar, unfortunately your attacks won’t always hit them if they are up the stairs or on another height  (it’s really annoying).
-I played Mage, and sometimes I felt like my character wasn’t responding to my commands ( while using ember lance, a kind of ray shooting from your hand) sometimes I was able to turn around while attacking to hit enemies coming from different directions and other times I just couldn’t, I was locked firing in the same direction.
-While doing the Dwarven Vault mission, I wanted to exit the portal and re-enter it, but the portal disappeared. I can understand it’s a secret portal, but why make it a one way only, I don’t understand the reason behind that. 
-my pet and myself sometimes got stuck, had to exit the game and that did the trick (got stuck behind a lever I had just activated).
-the teleportation skill of the mage worked much better in Diablo 2. (can only teleport a few meters away). 
-Mobs just suddenly appear when you approach their spawning point i gues (like console games).
-maps are re-used many times (some levels). 
-my pet sometimes decided it didn’t want to follow me and would go wander off, or just be idle while i got attacked. 


Game issues bugs/glitches encountered:
-got stuck a couple of times 
-pet didn't react like it should

To make it short, I played this game to experience Torchlight, because I’m a big fan of Diablo and Diablo 2, but would rather recommend to just skip this one and directly go play Torchlight 2, which is in many ways much better.

65936521.review:
A gem.

... and then another one.

I guess we've had a lot of practice with RPG's now. We know what works? 
I see a lot of people do them. 
I guess they're all pretty good. I don't know. 
I've only played this one.

Torchlight doesn't have a fancy, huge character arc. Lower case r in the rPG. Kill things, get stuff, progress. 
But from the moment you launch into that first dungeon, this little game will keep you hacking and slashing, far beneath the earths mantle, way past where you thought you gave a God damn. 

You will look for the bottom, but let me assure you, it is Bosses. Allll. The wayyyy. Down.

And loot. It just shits loot.

In fact, this is what it does best. Loot dispersal. Better than anyone.

God in heaven, look not harshly upon us sinners, because I have no way of knowing, definitively, what beastial tortures were performed, on whom, in some cold, unholy laboratory, to produce the algorithm of delight that this game uses to keep me killin' these little shits. 

I mean, there are people that I don't like. The world is full of them. But none that make me want to smash their little coconuts in like the bastards in this game. I don't know what it is. They just shit me. Just not enough to quit.

And the game seems adept at giving me just enough to keep the smack going as the enemies get progressively harder. Little things. Shiney things. Things that would hurt if you were on the wrong end of them. But they are given to me and not my enemy. So it is by divine right, that I smack the bejeesus out of the wrong doers that live beneath the ground. 

But there is a limit. There is always a limit. A point past which even the most jaded soul must say, "ENOUGH!" 
I have seen that place, where you lose the sky and become the thing that you hate. A shadowy thing. I thing that others would pursue into a hole, to slaughter.

I would say "flee while you can traveller, there is naught here but ruin!", but you would see it for the ruse that it is. 

There is loot. Great treasure houses full of it, built only to sate the hunger of those who plumb it's depths. To give might to the weakened. Vengance to the wronged. ... and cortisol to the corresponding receptors.

This is a game to fill your nights and your days. You have been warned.

Pets, minions, robots, quests, side quests.  You can do what you want, when you want, with no one bugging you about getting things done.  Has the same angle down view as Diablo, not a straight top-down view.  The characters, monsters, scenery, etc. are cartoonish, but the smooth gameplay kinda makes up for that. 65630097.review:
This game deserves all the love.
It's essentially Diablo 1 (even having some of the same devs). Go down through randomly generated levels of a dungeon. Kill more than 9000 enemies. Done!

What makes this game stand out, though, are all the little things about it. Lovingly crafted low poly asthetic. The pet system. The fast and fluid action gameplay. Oh, and the pet system, did I mention that?

It's not without its flaws, of course. The balancing of the base game could be better. It's over-all very easy side, even for non-action-RPG-veterans, but it also has some weirdly powerful enemies who's damage randomly spikes much higher than some bosses' sometimes. And the soundtrack could be better. It's very reminiscent of Diablo 1, but there isn't much of it and it starts repeating quickly.

But on the other hand, all those flaws are quickly alleviated with mod. Which really has to be shouted out. The game is so well optimized. It runs on pretty much anything, from the most shabby old grandpa laptop, to the most outlandish high-end powerhouse. On all recent Windows versions and even on my Linux PCs. 

The second game may yet be better, but the first surely is a great game in its own right!

TL;DR: Only purchase Torchlight if you want some nostalgia, otherwise it's completely unbalanced on hard mode with tanky enemies who also deal way too much damage, even if you're 8 levels higher than them, you'll still die easily mid- to late game, gold economy is a joke too.

Torchlight 1, a game that clearly shows its time of release, with low textures and simplistic meshes. Which I find absolutely find, but what I don't find okay, is to make hard mode just to make monsters tanky and deal as much damage as a tank, while still spitting loot that's 90% of the time useless, in addition to the enchantment being nigh useless due to the price of enchantment being way too expensive to be useful.
The gold economy is just terrible, you loot between 3 to about ~70 gold piles at level 25+, and the vendor prices sell items that roll about ~300 gold and items being about over 3000 gold. 64543586.review:
Torchlight is a fantasy point-and-click isometric dungeon crawler in exactly the same format that fans of this genre will undoubtedly have seen countless times before. But, despite being generically milquetoast at release and a bit dated in 2020, it’s still recommendable for a number of reasons, to both longtime IDC fans and those just looking for a simple introduction to the format.

Torchlight’s own take on the dungeon crawler formula is to avoid the dark and “mature” tone of the cult-classic Diablo and the pseudo-realistic take on mythology à la Titan Quest and instead opts for a young adult fantasy novel-esqe aesthetic as if Torchlight is simultaneously trying to be almost edgy yet remain grounded in a distinct cartoony artstyle.  

The titular Torchlight is a backwater mining town built over the most recently discovered physical source of magic in this world, and uses the mines and natural caverns under the town as the setting the player must explore several dozen pre-determined levels of in order to resolve a really lacklustre plot complication, as clearly written by a programmed-centric development team that knew game mechanics are the thing here that really matters.  

This aforementioned core focus on gameplay and interestingly diverse levels as you reach further into the deeper levels under the NPC merchant-filled homebase of the town is Torchlight’s strongest point. The game goes so far as to narrow its choice of class and skillset to just three entirely separate classes (ranged/DPS rogue, tanky melee warrior, or mob-summoning wizard), - without appearance customisation options no less, for better or worse. Regardless of whichever class you choose, you’ll be up against the same dungeon design and the same waves on enemies, although the whole thing does seem to fall on the forgiving side of the difficulty curve on even the hardest of the three difficulty options. 

Everything mentioned so far is all well and good if you’re just looking for a generic isometric monster clicker, but, I would go as far as stating that the appeal in Torchlight now is the large modding scene it has attracted in the eleven years that have gone by since release. Runic Games has always incentivised modding in their game - going as far as including Steam Achievements for installing them. The simplicity of Torchlight belies a blank canvas for enterprising upstart wannabe-devs to create their own additions to the game (*cough* making excuses *cough*). 

There is a whole world of custom content for this game, and the tools to make your own come part and parcel with the Steam version too! I can’t list any here, because of Valve’s trigger happy health-and-safety-gone-mad approach to removing links, but if only for the potential encompassed in the game’s engine-editing tools, I’d recomended it, especially if you happen to see it on sale.

Recommended.

64214031.review:
Oh, to be 10 years old again, running over to the neighbor’s house to play Diablo because I was afraid to ask my parents for the game. When Diablo 2 came out he gave me his copy of the first one and I was obsessed. It was a transitional period of my life, as I grew from child to teenager, able to play games for adults rather than just Mario and friends for the first time. The difference between the first games simple decent into hell from Tristram and the second’s sprawling world was exactly where my life was at the time.
Just like Diablo 1 & 2, the Torchlight games have the same path. The first is a simple decent into a dungeon with 3 generic archetypes as classes and the second being the critically acclaimed game that learned from all the hardships of the first. Unlike Diablo though, there are no nostalgia glasses to put on. The difficulty curve, the simple classes, the unexplained magic system all feel like relics from the past. 
Of course, I understand that this is exactly the selling point of Torchlight. Peel back all the streamlining that came with the Diablo games and turn it back to when an ARPG would willingly one shot you. There is a careful balancing act that must happen to make that fun and for every moment it gets the balance correct, it has just as many that fall short and are frustrating. 
There are times when I am one-shot with no real idea what killed me or how to prevent it next time. There are skills in the skill tree that don’t do anything exciting, adding dmg to your basic attack or lowering requirements for spells. Where the modern games have bound health potion to a specific key, here it is still something that takes the place of a main skill, and you’ll be using it lots. 
There is a mess of loot, but most of it will be sold. You see the occasional epic or set item and quickly level up past the point that it is useful. In many ways it feels like WoW Classic in that an upgrade can mean going from 3 dex to 4 dex. Even an upgrade doesn’t feel exciting. One new addition to the genre is a pet that will go to town and sell all the loot you don’t need, a small concession that doesn’t really fix the problem of too much useless loot. 
In some ways it feels clunky. Casting can’t happen while auto-attacking and often I couldn’t get heal spell off in time because of the auto-attack animation. Sometimes clicking on an enemy was hard to do as a ranged class and I would inevitably run right into the mess of battle and die. When summoning minions to help me, often they would spawn on the opposite side of the screen as the enemies, and my help would idle around because they were out of range of the monsters killing me. Its small quality of life things that add up over time and make the game frustrating.
Despite the outdated and undercooked feel of many of the mechanics, the game has a lot of charm. Some of that comes from the stripped back to Diablo 1 feel of a single descending dungeon to tackle with 3 basic classes. Elsewhere the charm comes from the cartoony style. As much as Diablo looked dark and edgy to me at 10, I prefer the blocky comic style of Torchlight. Here it takes lots of visual cues from WoW again and it is fun. 
Overall the frustrations outweigh the fun in this first installment, and it’s hard to justify playing it over its older brother Torchlight 2. Who gets most of those things right and expands the game to Diablo 2 levels of perfection on the back of this simple first game.

63793407.review:
[h1]Torchlight is a lovely game in the spirit of Diablo or Divine Divinity and other action role-playing games that have come before it.[/h1] It doesn't reinvent the wheel, but it also doesn't attempt to - it's quite comfortable refining an existing formula and it does it rather well. 

Torchlight is easy to pick up and play regardless of whether you're a seasoned player or these kinds of games or if it's your first time. Want your character to move somewhere on the screen? Just click on the spot. Want to attack an enemy? Just click on it. As the game progresses there are more gameplay elements added, but by and large it keeps everything rather simple. It should be noted that, like many games in this genre, it is perhaps slightly too easy in terms of difficulty - at least for returning players - and so bumping the difficulty up at the start of the game is advisable to keep it challenging and fun. At the core of Torchlight is running through dungeons, killing monsters and gathering loot. There is a story, but it's one that doesn't take itself too seriously and that (thankfully) never gets in the way of the gameplay. Again, Torchlight is a game that knows that the primary focus here isn't on dialogue, world building, character development or story in general; the main focus is on the gameplay. Add to that the fact that Torchlight is a beautiful game to look at, having a distinct and consistent art style that permeates the entire in-game world is a really rather nice touch that makes the experience of playing it all the more enjoyable. I should note here that the music is also fantastic, changing along with the gameplay and while also being discrete enough to not distract from it. 

Are there problems with Torchlight? Well, it should go without saying - but yes, there are issues. Little things like managing your inventory occasionally get needlessly cumbersome, and a few bigger things like enemy texture models popping in and out of existence do undoubtedly detract somewhat from the experience, but far from enough to ruin it. It should also be kept in mind that Torchlight came out in 2009, and since then much has happened within the genre to improve certain game mechanics and whatnot. 

[b]All told, Torchlight is well worth picking up and playing in 2020 and beyond.[/b] It's a charming game that allows you to hop in and out as you wish, never demanding too much time from you while also providing you with more than enough content for those days when you just want to keep going. :-)

59648783.review:
I have been getting into ARPGs a lot, recently and after playing Diablo, I decided to pick Torchlight up. I'll say, overall, I really like this game and it is fun to play. But, it is also very repetitive, especially if you try to do everything. A big issue is that the maps don't really feel different despite the different skins and the game play is not very deep at all compared to its Diablo counter part. It is good for some mindless fun but it isn't good for a deep dive concentrated binge in my opinion.

I'm going to be honest, this game would only need some minor changes to be so much better. It really comes down to certain things been a let down more than the game being poorly made by any extent. One issue is that the bosses are not really bosses. They are just bigger enemies and they appear constantly, only being marginally harder than a regular enemy. I was hoping that when I came across one, I would feel a tense moment where I would have to take a second and think about how to approach it. But, like most of the time, I went in with guns blazing with very little consequence. This alone makes the game way too easy. On Normal, I hardly felt much difficulty at all. It is fine for the normal enemies to be fodder as long as the bosses had more interesting aspects to them. Like behavioral differences or anything that made that feel more engaging. Everything else wrong would be 100% ignorable if this one simple thing has been dealt with differently. Though, with that said, the last boss is exactly what I wanted. Tough, interesting and different from the rest. Even if it was still kind of basic, it has at least scratched that itch.

Another issue is something that I have seen in a few different games that I am not a fan of in RPGs and that is the fact that the quests aren't quests. They are milestones. One is just a constant reoccurring quest to kill the bosses you were going to kill anyways with just a little bonus in rewards. The other is collecting different types of unusable embers from certain levels, which I guess is more of a quest than the first but still feels more bare bones than anything. And the third is a guy who opens up a separate portal to ask you to do more or less the same thing as the second guy, which kind of brings me to my next issue...

There is this aspect in this game that I actually kind of like. Extra dungeons. Including the guy I mentioned before, there are also maps you can buy or gain as rewards for these quests. You active them and they usually bring you to a two level dungeon. I liked this idea and felt it had a lot of potential...But in the end, it sadly made the game seem more repetitive and artificially lengthened. These maps aren't much different than the main dungeon, using the same skins as certain levels. Which, I feel was a real missed opportunity to make something different. Would have been cool to, after running through what is generally a generated dungeon with map chunks, play through something with a more handcrafted feel, even if it ended up being shorted. I think with the Boss aspect I mentioned earlier, this hit really hard. And then there are these portal beasts. You kill them and they leave behind a portal. Which is another idea I really like and granted, was performed slightly better with the portals usually leading to a short level where you get bombarded with powerful enemies. It really gets the blood pumping in comparison.

The other issue with the extra dungeons though is it is really easy to become over leveled for the main dungeon that was already kind of on the easy side. Though, I think had I not put in time with a handful of the extra dungeons, the game would not have felt so repetitive and I would have found myself enjoying it more and maybe a little less easy. Even if it would still have been both of those things. It is just a shame that something I actually found to be a cool idea actually ends up hurting the game a little.

With that said, where the game shines, it really shines. Because it was still fun to play. There are mods to fix up some of these issues; expanding possible map chunks to make the map less repetitive, as well as difficulty adjustments and so on. One really cool thing about this game is they are very open to the mod community and there are plenty of mods to look into and I might give this game another run with them and see if they help.

I don't want to give the wrong idea because a review with mostly negative things to mention seems like a negative review but honestly I recommend this game. For the price, it isn't bad at all and on sale it is definitely worth the buy. Just don't expect the difficulty of diablo or anything like that. Overall, I give this game a 7 out of 10. 58799654.review:
I first played Torchlight over a decade ago at release. I was enthralled by the game and fell in love with the world, characters, and gameplay. As a child I was introduced to the ARPG genre through the classic game FATE and had always wanted more of the same. So let me tell you when Torchlight first graced my screen I was smitten and bought the game right away after expiring the one hour demo that was available at the time. 

And now here I am writing a review for a game I've played on and off for the last decade. I can say with for certain this is an amazing game and there is no reason you shouldn't buy and play Torchlight either. The game is compatible with modern systems and it's graphical appeal still stands today with sharp visuals that give the game its own unique look. 

Let's not forget the classic dungeon hack n' slash loot-a-thon gameplay we all love as well. Torchlight starts at a little slow but once you have a proper character build going you'll be mowing down hordes of hideous fiends and dastardly foes for all the gleaming gold you can stuff in your insatiable pockets. 

Three classes which break down to Melee, Range, or Magic. A variety of NPC's to help the player (Enchanter, Transmuter, Gemmers, Gambler, etc.) and even an infinite random dungeon known as the Shadow Crypt you can explore forever after the game's main quest is complete. 

The game even supports mods and many are still available and working to this day from various fan sites. 

Torchlight is a classic. 
Torchlight slaps.
Torchlight treats everyone with respect.
Torchlight is that cool person at the party everyone likes.
Feeling down? Torchlight is there for you bro.

I don't know what else to say other than Torchlight is a great game worth every penny and if you like any of the other entries in the Torchlight series then you will likely enjoy Torchlight as well.

58689463.review: Great RPG, adventure, dungeon crawler, Diablo-like game.  :)

58599461.review:
There are better ARPGs out there by now but I would still recommend the game if you just want to play a different game for a casual playthrough or you want to take a history lesson in ARPGs since Torchlight actually managed to sell over 2 million copies. You can choose one of three classes that each also have 3 talent trees. You loot some items, level up, pick a few active and passive skills, kill some bosses and go through a few different areas with a variety of enemies. The story is nothing to write home about but it does not need to be.

The longer you play the game though the more problems become apparent and especially my playthrough on Very Hard Hardcore made some of these painfully obvious. Here are some of the gripes I had with the game:

[b]Items:[/b]
[list]
[*]less than 1% of the items you find are even remotly useful
[*]the number of different attributes an item can roll is way too huge and there are a lot of useless ones
[*]you are still forced to collect all of the crap items to make some gold which makes it annoying and a waste of time
[*]the best items you can get do not drop but you just buy them from the vendor
[*]armor and resistances reduce the damage you take by a flat amount which does not really help against damage spikes (esp. on higher difficulties)
[*]there are item sets but these items are quite bad and you most likely will not be able to get even one set bonus when playing through the whole game
[/list]
[b]Enchanting:[/b]
[list]
[*]costs a lot of gold, can completly destroy the item, can fail, you have no control, and you can get a lot of useless stats
[*]being able to come back to an early floor because there are shrines of enchantment seems like a design error because it encourages you to repeatedly do easy content or just run around to upgrade your gear
[/list]
[b]Skills:[/b]
[list]
[*]even on the hardest difficulty you can just pick only one active skill and put the rest of your skill points into passive skils which makes the gameplay quite boring
[/list]
[b]Gems:[/b]
[list]
[*]give very little stats compared to gear and should probably just be ignored since they take up a lot of space in your stash and it takes some time to combine them, you might only use them in weapon sockets
[/list]
[b]Difficulty:[/b]
[list]
[*]on easier difficulties you can probably play without any gear because it is irrelevant and on higher difficulties you just need a lot of health rolls on your gear the game does not become harder in any other way
[/list]
[b]Pet:[/b]
[list]
[*]your pet constantly dies on higher difficulties
[*]while you can send your pet to town to sell items, it takes quite a long time, your pet cannot help you in combat during that time and it is probalby easier and faster if you just sell the items yourself
[/list]
[b]Maps:[/b]
[list]
[*]while it is nice that you can buy maps you have little to no control over the level of the map or which maps you can buy since they scale to your own level which makes them too hard on higher difficulties
[/list]

57083636.review:
Solid Diablo-like that is the most faithful reproduction of the core concepts of Diablo 1 I have ever seen with some major quality of life improvements (a pet to always have something to aggro, extra inventory space, run to town and sell items). Makes sense given the game is the baby of the folks who put together the superb Diablo 1 and Diablo 2.

Long and short of it is you descend downward into a procedurally generated dungeon that has 4-5 major templates, ocassionally doing runs in alternate scaled dungeons accessed by killing Phase beasts, purchasing maps, or completing alternate quests. Not much of a story to speak of other than "seek out the evil beneath the town".

Played the game as a summoner mage, but focused on ranged weapons as opposed to magic. The game was remarkably forgiving with this weird cross class set-up and deaths never felt cheap or unfair. Felt great rolling through waves of enemies as a high crit sniper with a ton of minions to provide cover.

Graphics have that soft cartoon-ish early WOW look to them and although I didn't play the game on a netbook, the fact that a "netbook mode" is part of the setting suggests this game could be run on a potato.

Great game to play while you're trying to watch a show or just want to keep your clicking finger exercised as the game really does not require much attention, especially with a small army of minions.

56339014.review:
After getting the TL 1 & 2 as a pack, I never played them!

I am a massive Diablo fan, and although it is a diablo-esque top down dungeon crawler with set-pieces in common, it is a completely different and novel game.

A fun dungeon crawler with an entertaining story and fun mechanics!

I particularly enjoy the ability to mix things up a bit on your own terms! If you want to go and do story that's fine, but there is also 'maps' that open portals to loot filled little dungeons that, although samey, break up the chunky mine.

It's also handy as they are inexpensive to buy from merchants and you will reap rewards greater than the investment, so a handy money / material spinner for when you need to stock up.

7.5/10 Will complete both as they are fun games with that pick up and play ability for those of us short on time and willpower!

56251757.review:
Antes de empezar, el juego tiene una version en Español pero deben buscarla por google, es del juego orignial que por alguna razon no existe hoy día para las versiones digitales pero que igual sirve. Ahora si mi opinión

Un "clon Diablo" (palabra del genero que casi no se usa hoy) clásico que dejara satisfechos a veteranos del genero y nuevos, fue hecho con mucho mimo y talento, con su toque propio, siendo de los creadores originales de Diablo y una pequeña saga llamada Fate.

Realmente el juego mezcla conceptos de Diablo y Fate pero mejorandolos, por dar un ejemplo tenemos una mascota que cumple funcion de mochila, apoyo y guerrera, esta misma mascota ademas de poder transformarse con peces puede usar conrujos (desde hacer invocaciones hasta lanzar hechizos) y aparte sirve como una mochila extra que puede ir a vender los objetos que entremos sin tener que abrir un portal para ir al pueblo.  Este es un ejemplo por mencionar uno pues tiene varios, pero es mas divertido que los descubran.

El juego cuenta con 3 clases pero sus skills son todas utiles y ademas tienen skills para poder usar items de las demás clases pudiendo variar mucho las builds, para tener por ejemplo un guerrero-tanque que use arco y flecha o un hechicero que use invocacioens y con hacha en mano pelee junto a ellas, etc. En si mismo a su vez todas las skills son utiles, cosa que en otros juegos del genero generalmente las primeras skills pierden importancia en el progreso de la partida aun si son maxeadas, cosa que aquí no pasa.

Por otro lado su dificultad esta bien, para novatos es una buena introduccion, aunque para veteranos será facil a cierto punto, siendo su dificultad maxima (que se puede elegir desde el inicio) la adecuada, aún así seguira siendo relativamente facil, aunque da un subidon de dificultad en sus niveles finales. (De hecho yo a maxima dificultad iba muriendo 2 veces solamente, llegue a los niveles finales y rápidamente llegue a 15 muertes).  Por tanto en dificultad va a ser entretenido para todos los niveles, pero sobre el final puede ser un reto este juego.

Hablando de lo "malo" es generalmente por la falta de presupuesto imagino por que fue el primer juego de un grupo de desarrolladores con recursos muy limitados, esto llevo a por ejemplo no tener multiplayer (cosa que mods lo solucionaron ) y que rejugabilidad puede ser limitada, ya que al jugarlo 3 veces ya recordaras el mapeado que es bastante limitada la variedad de escenarios que tiene cada nivel de mazmorra. (cosa que para esto también salieron mods).

En conclusión es un juego que tiene sus limitaciones por ser el primer juego de Runic Games y ser algo "pequeño", pero sin dudas mantiene una calidad atemporal, yo lo jugue en su día y ahora lo volvi a jugar para Steam casi 10 años despues y pueden ver por mis horas de juego que lo sigo disfrutando.

55358526.review:
If you enjoy the Diablo franchise, or more specifically; the first Diablo, and you want more of EXACTLY that - you might find some entertainment here. It is a direct copy of that game after all. It's made by some of the same guys so it's no shock. The gameplay is fairly tight and responsive in its simplicity and the animations are smooth enough. The atmosphere is pretty nice, but only thanks to the fantastic soundtrack (same composer as well).

The innovation is absolutely nowhere to be seen though. It's almost stupidly basic in its execution. It's too much of a clone, actually, considering Diablo was released in 1996. Pretty much the only new thing added is the pet, which adds nothing to the gameplay - apart from not having to visit town every other minute to sell junk. You can equip the pet with spells and customize them a bit, but it barely makes any difference. Make it a summoner and you have some extra cannon fodder at least.

There's barely any dialogue and the story is told very sparsely (it all breaks down to; go deeper). This means you get right into the action - no cinematics, no cutscenes, no bla-bla. This is what some people want, so; fair enough. 

Stats are extremely basic, and so are the skills. This means the game is VERY easy to get into for a newcomer to the genre. And it's very easy to play. Harder difficulties are still hard - but the game itself is easy to play. But.. this is also a problem. The game gets too repetitive too fast. The environments are meh and the skills are not exciting enough to sustain it.

Overall, the game is fairly decent. It does NOTHING new, but nothing outright bad either. It feels like a budget title, as it is, and it should be thought of as such. I swayed between a positive or negative review score while writing this, solely because it's not outright bad and might have an appeal for beginners to the genre. Still, there are better games like this out there. A lot of them.

It's also completely and utterly overshadowed by Torchlight II, and is made pretty much obsolete because of it. With that in mind, no, it's not recommended.

54505161.review:
Pros:
+ Art style that ages well
+ Easy to get into
+ Understated yet effective soundtrack
+ Sending your pet to town to sell items
+ Optional dungeons
+ Transmuting gems is free $w$
+ Your pet can learn spells

Cons:
- No way to change key bindings in-game; you have to go to the wiki for it instead - https://torchlight.fandom.com/wiki/Keybinding_(T1)
- Voice acting is so-so
- Secondary npcs don't have voice acting
- Map can be hard to read due to transparency and mods are needed to fix this
- No controller support despite it being released on XBLA
- No way to respec skill points

This game is a good choice if you want a lite RPG though I'd recommend the sequel instead, especially since that one also features co-op and has aged better in terms of accessibility.
