50840765.review:
I really enjoyed Torchlight maybe 8 or 9 years ago.
I've replayed it recently and find it a pretty terrible game.

It's very similar to Diablo I in structure, although its pacing (which includes length and skill tree) are closer to Diablo II. Unfortunately, it's a straightforward tribute and suffers from exactly the same problems Diablo II did.

There are three major problems that ruin the game, for me:
(1) Extremely monotonous, formulaic and uniform structure. The game is purely about clearing dungeons. There is no real story or quests - the three side quests that exist do not change the experience in any way. You go through 4 identical floors of a dungeon. Then you have a boss fight. Then the theme changes, the enemies change, and the cycle repeats. This goes on 7 times (for 35 floors).

You don't really explore or exploit anything in the dungeons. They also get longer for no reason. In most games, you would call this "filler". The combat is fun, but it is also rather compulsive. It's satisfying to crowd control, but there isn't much to it beyond visceral satisfaction.

(2) Game is about PLANNING rather than RESPONDING. You get 2 skill points per level (there are actually two different kinds of XP, each giving you one skill point - but that is largely irrelevant, since they are in synch). Early on, this is fine. Later on, as you need more and more XP, these get very scarce.
Early on, the game is easy, and so you play the game for fun. You put points into whatever skills sound fun and work. At this point, the game is good.
Later on, however, there is a huge difficulty spike. And you can't predict it. The game doesn't slowly change the challenges it throws at you. So you keep building a character that works, until it suddenly doesn't. When it doesn't, you can't really change your build. At least not without grind.
Since you can't respec your character, you're largely at the mercy of what the game decides to throw at you. The skills also scale terribly, and later skills are almost necessary since they're much better than early skills (regardless of your gear or how many points you put into them).

The lack of respec is the biggest issue, to me. You can't really experiment with different skills.
Which is why you have so many people "min-maxing" and going online in search for the "optimal build". The game doesn't really give you a chance to respond to a challenge, forcing you to make the correct choice from the start.

(3) Again, the game is pure filler.
This has two main aspects. The first is that you have essentially the same dungeon (with minor map variations) 4 times, plus the boss. The second is that the skill tree has 10 points to put into each skill/passive.
The result, to me, is a game that is stretched beyond what is interesting. The repeated floors are there to let you earn enough XP to get those 10 points per skill, or vice-versa. 

Coupled with the lack of respec, this is a surprising problem. Because each class can be played in different ways. And there are 3 different classes. So why not have a shorter game that encourages experimentation with different specializations or classes? Why stretch a single game for so long, and prevent you from trying different playstyles?

___

Anyway. I honestly find the game very bad. I didn't enjoy Diablo II either, for largely the same reasons (2 and 3, mostly; 1 is also present, but in a less direct way).
Perhaps the online component and the status of rare items changes the context of the dungeoneering/filler. Even then, however, the game becomes a slot machine, in my opinion.

Although this is likely to be an unpopular opinion, I feel like ARPGs (at least traditional ones like Diablo and Torchlight) would benefit immensely from the modern Roguelite structure. It's a lot about making the main dungeoneering loop more interesting by presenting a lot more choices and ways to exploit the random nature of the loot.
Since you also use a small number of skills, even the combat could be probably changes to a more MOBA-like style, like Battlerite. 
But maybe this is blasphemy.
 
Anyway. If you like Diablo, you should like this. It's the same game, minus the incredible atmosphere of the former.
I guess I don't.

50451722.review:
Please head over to AndrewsBase to check out the full review.  Unfortunately, I had to manage my word count on the Steam Review and each paragraph may not flow as I originally intended: http://andrewsbase.com/2019/05/03/torchlight-review-a-lethargic-arpg-experience-that-does-not-hold-up-nearly-a-decade-after-launch/

orchlight is an Action-RPG in the same vein as all of your genre defining favourites like Diablo, Path of Exile, Titan Quest and Grim Dawn that released a decade ago and was a huge hit on the old Xbox Live Arcade. Runic Games ceased trading in 2017 and have since rebirthed under the Echtra Games label with Diablo and Torchlight co-creator Max Schaefer at the helm and are currently developing Torchlight Frontiers. I thought now would be a good time to venture in to the world of Torchlight.

[h1]Ember.  It lives in us all[/h1]

If you have ever played a ARPG like Blizzard’s ever-popular Diablo series, you will know exactly what Torchlight is and what it offers. If not, Torchlight is an isometric, mouse-controlled Action-RPG where you must slay every shuffling enemy that presents itself while utilizing a unique set of abilities, weapons and armour while hording every darn piece of loot that emanates from every corpse.

Torchlight offers the choice of three classes which can be boiled down to their basics; a melee focused Destroyer, a magic wielding Alchemist and the range-oriented Vanquisher, with each offering their own unique class abilities and playstyles. For this particular review I was an all-powerful magic casting Alchemist named Azrael who focused on conjuring an array of spells to dispose of the ungodly inhabitants of a mysterious mine.

The game instantly hit me with an incredibly bland and uninspired story that I had very little interest from the get-go and that interest very quickly waned. Set in the town of Torchlight, the local mine is laden with a all-magical substance named Ember that holds power beyond all imagination and corrupts the very bones of those that dare harvest it. It is this exact substance that is empowering a never-ending spawn of creatures and demons that are serving as protection for their master who is encased at the bottom of the mine. As interesting as this sounds, it all falls completely flat with utterly laughable voice acting and miniscule story bites that are strewn thinly throughout the campaign.

Every piece of dialogue is served either via a loading screen with one to two paragraphs of text or a small text box during gameplay, this is further confirmed when the story culminated in a singular sentence of a NPC mumbling thank you for your help, before quickly leaving.

So you’ve picked your class and decided on whether to bring along a dog or a cat as a companion and pack mule that you forcibly stack full of items and send to the games only town to sell and return with your hard-earned cash. This reduces the amount of trips needed to remove junk from your inventory as your fluffy compatriot has the same inventory size as your chosen hero. Not content with being a sentient item wheelbarrow, Mittens or Spot will fight by your side recklessly and constantly flee as their health drains from enemy attacks. However it is possible to buff your furry friend by teaching them spells from spell scrolls or feeding them fish in a bid to transform them in to some gelatinous blob or spider, whatever your preference.

The town of Torchlight is the only hub in the game and is the only location outside of the mine.  Exciting, I know.  The town is not vast but it had everything I needed to keep my adventure going and is where I picked up all of my very similar quests before delving back in to the depths below. The sub quests are handed out by lifeless Townie’s  and are the exact same every time. I got bored with the robot-bard that asked me to hunt mini-bosses, which were only higher tiered enemies, or the mage tasking me with collecting the corrupting substance Ember – no thanks, I am attempting to put a halt to the corruption that is spilling out from these glowing rocks, not infect everyone!

Speaking of NPC’s, the dank, dark and depressing town of Torchlight acts as a hub to sell items, enhance gear, gamble and make use of the shared stash.  I actively avoided leaving the mine unless it was to scoop up side-quests with each tier using the same, tired dialogue or to buy health and mana potions. Like a demanding boss I drove my poor doggo to exhaustion as I made full use of the return to town option, selling all of my junk as I forced myself to go from floor to floor, fighting very comparable foes at every corner.

[h1]Hitting the grind[/h1]

Combat feels incredibly satisfying, something which I regard highly in the ARPG space – if it feels good to smash through thousands of enemies for a undetermined number of hours, then that is a positive in my book. In Torchlight mulching enemies with a staff, axe or sword feels powerful and weighted while magical spells are entrancing and have nice looking elemental effects, even a decade on.

This is coupled with one of the best in genre soundtracks as Torchlight is packed to the brim with eery, guitar-strumming goodness. It reminded me of previous Diablo titles and rightly so as it is composed by Matt Uelmen of Diablo fame.

Tying combat together is an uninspiring levelling system that leaves a lot to be desired. Each class has three separate skill trees all with their own unlockable physical and passive skills as well as a generic place a point in to strength, dexterity, magic or defense system. Every level up provided me with a skill point while generating fame by fighting mini-bosses let me place a stat point in to one of the three skill trees that each class had access to. For example, on my Alchemist I had the choice to venture down the dark path of necromancy, the strength of a battle wizard or to be more traditional and make use of magical spells. Each skill can be levelled up 10 times increasing its potency, damage and a manner of other relevant stats.

The actual act of placing points in to each skill was a drag and added to the lethargy I was feeling towards Torchlight.  Something so simple as allowing me to build my character in the way that I want should not be gated off by an arbitrary levelling system. I wanted to max out a skill that boosted my magic stat and I was constantly forced to either not use that skill point and save it for later, until I reached the games desired character level, or place that point in a different skill, where I would be unable to recover it as there is no option to respec. I felt I wasn’t in control of my character build and I was being railroaded down certain tracks that the developer had predetermined.

While we are discussing character builds, Torchlight is utterly bereft of any stat screen, to my unmitigated bemusement. A video game which is centred around gathering loot and becoming increasingly more powerful to strike down tougher foes doesn’t give me the tools to truly get down to the nitty-gritty of min-maxing my character or even at times figuring out which weapon is better suited to my build. You will not find health on hit, armour block percentages, damage numbers, minion damage, mana per second, magic find, thorns or anything that you would expect to see.

There was a surprising upswing in difficulty towards the end, a difficulty that was not present in the previous 95% of the game as I minced my way through hordes of corrupted enemies monotonously. Average enemies, mini-bosses, full on story related bosses and everything in-between were no match for my build and then I hit floor 31.  Oh how naive and unprepared I was as my first brush here seen me get pushed aside like a crisp packet in the wind as the previously laughably easy enemies melted their way through my armour and build in seconds. Taunting me as they paraded my corpse to their overlords.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

SCORE: 1.5/5

49601013.review:
Urrrrffff - Where do I start? I want to love Torchlight. If you've never seen a gamesoft like this, Torchlight is an overhead action game that has you exploring a randomly generated dungeon as you dive ever deeper into it's depths to gain experience points, new abilities, and obtain new, hopefully more powerful, randomly generated armor, weapons, and trinkets.

The aesthetic is wonderful. The art style has personality and the locals differ just enough to keep it's random nature interesting. What I'm not crazy about is the core gameplay. I played through as the "Destroyer," the game's melee brawler. The majority of the game, I breezed through it - enemies crumbled at my feet and spoils were plentiful. But, there was never much strategy to my destruction. Enemies were hard to read and, due to not being in direct control of your character, I didn't see much of a tactic to efficiently avoid danger. It usually boiled down to killing them before they killed you and, by the final boss, making sure I drank a steady supply of potions. My other bane of this game was the before mentioned loot - most of it is garbage. I felt like I spent more time disappointingly poking through my spoils then fighting for it.

My gut feeling is that these grievances are simply what people expect from a "Diablo-like" such as Torchlight. Although I've had an idea what kind of game a "Diablo-like" is since Diablo came out, I've never actually gone far into one until now.
I didn't hate my time in Torchlight, but I am happy to finally leave it.

TL;DR - Combat feel basic, yo. Too easy, then too hard. Grindy grindy grind grind. Death is meaningless.

49452539.review:
Torchlight is an action RPG, made by some of the guys who did Diablo 1 and 2. That is practically where the similarities end, however, as this world is much brighter than the Diablo games, and does not have quite the same level of complexity in terms of builds, etc.

The story is pretty generic - town is being overrun and you must dive into the caves and save the world, etc. You certainly won't be playing this game for plot. There are three classes available - Destroyer, Vanquisher and Alchemist (again, quite standard for an action RPG). The skill tree and points do allow for a fair amount of variety, and itemisation also plays a big role, with set items being particularly useful.

I also found the endless dungeon system to be particularly engaging, as the floors go on forever and get progressively more difficult the further you go. This is where you will spend your time - the end game - once you have finished the story mode. The heirloom system was also a very nice touch: you can "retire" a character, and choose one of their items to pass on to a new character, upgrading it significantly in the process. The ability to mod the game, changing almost every aspect of it, is also a big positive and really adds to the experience - highly recommended to get some mods and try them out.

One thing to bear in mind before purchasing: there is no multiplayer functionality whatsoever - you will be playing this solo, and it did get a little tedious for me after a while.

Recommended for those looking for something casual, and for those who enjoy their action RPGs.

Played on Windows 10 Pro x64 without any issues.

49418831.review:
As much as I enjoyed Torchlight 2, I was really hoping the OG Torchlight would scratch that itch for a casual ARPG looter with fast paced action and tons of monsters to destroy. Unfortunately, the original leaves quite a bit to be desired and it was ultimately a glitch that lead to me uninstalling the game.

First, you cannot manually save and there are no saves for you to go back to. This may not seem like a big deal until you run into the glitch I did. My character was attacked to a tile, unable to move, and with the Town Portal Scroll unable to be activated because reasons. Since I can't load to a prior save, my character is basically stuck and if I want to proceed I need to start over. Granted, I don't mind starting over in games. The gods know I do it enough in titles with heavy survival elements, but a b*tch is not doing that in a game where she's already 9 hours deep into the main campaign. 

On top of this, the dungeons, and environments, are repetitive. Each dungeon has about 3-4 exact levels that are simply duplicates with the same kind of enemies, architecture, and lay out that increase in difficulty the deeper into the dungeon you go. If you're a competent min-maxer who's good with your equipment, you'll find little challenge no matter how deep you go. You can definitely tell where  they made improvements in the sequel with mixing up the scenery, and enemies, so you don't get too bored but In this title, you'll eventually start just blasting through the hordes just so you can get to something that feels new. 

There's no crafting, with the extent of your customization of weapons, armor, and trinkets tied to enchantment wells you find in the wild. This isn't a big deal to me but if you're looking to be able to modify weapons beyond luck/random drops and a couple of gem sockets, this really won't be the game for you. Transmutation of gems seems to be the deepest the game goes into creating effects for your gear.

There are few classes to choose from and what you can choose offers 3 branches you can sink skill points into for enhancing your character. From what I've seen, the perks seem to be level based so you're not locked into putting points into skills you won't use just to get to something you'll actually deploy. They unlock regardless of where you've put points before which is great when you want a hyper focused build. 

Sad to say, the game gets boring after about 5 hours. I am one of those people who likes to explore every nook and cranny of a game's world and when the world turns out to be recycled and plain dull, I lose interest pretty quick. All in all,  It was the completionist in me that wanted to finish this game. It wasn't the story line or the game play itself. It was fairly easy for me to shrug and say "oh well" when I realized I wouldn't be able to move forward with my latest play through and I have no desire to start over just to get to the end. If you're looking for a good loot heavy ARPG, I would definitely recommend Torchlight 2 but this one might be best left to those coming back for nostalgia.

It’s a small thing but upon completing the game your hero’s legacy lives on in a piece of legendary equipment. it's a great ARPG to introduce people to the genre. but it is easily outdone by it’s sequel.

48081876.review:
I absolutely love this game and it'll always be on my top 5 list. 

[h1] Intro [/h1]

It's an excellent alternative to the Diablo games, seeing that the developers are some of the original developers of those games. 
They have added their own touch with the cartoony style and cool effects for weapons etc.
What have stayed the same is the componist of the music. He's the same who made the OST for Diablo, so music wise it got the same atmosphere.

[h1]Customization[/h1] 

There's not much customization besides the stats, skills, armor and how you'll place your items on the bar. 
The Engineer, Vanguard and Barbarian got their separate fixed look and you can only choose between 2 pets (unless you cheat). For the last part the pets can be transmuted with fish for a time. 

They have however added those things to Torchlight II: 4 classes, you can change hairstyle/hair colour/faces on all of them and got over 10 different pets to choose from. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

It got an exciting plot which leads you through different quests until a certain point when you get closer to the final boss. It's not all perfect bc to get all the achievements you'll have to complete the game with all the classes, on every floor (till 101 in a separate dungeon and not the one where the Ordrak is) and in every mode there is. 
It can get a bit tedious and repeating yes, however it also makes you feel triumph for each of them you succeed and overall find it entertaining. 

[h1]Rating: 8/10 [/h1]

48045158.review:
In the beginning Runic Games launched this game for free, little time after the first teaser for Diablo 3, and they marketed  over the fact that the team had some of the original Diablo 1 developers, and a lot of throwbacks to classic Diablo were made. After the success of the free launch, they've added some new featres (e.g. level editor) and published the comercial version of the game.

Now does the game feel like Diablo 1? Unfortunately, no. It has some throwbacks: The tristram-like town; 3 classes: fighter, caster, rogue; the huge dungeon below the city. But aside from that, mostly it incorporates mainstream overused trends of modern Hack'n'slashes and the final result simply screams "Generic". Everything in the game is extremely modular: All the quests are the same, only varying on the dungeon, creature and reward levels; all the dungeon incredibly similar save some very small gimmicks, with only the art changing; all the enemies are very similar also; same for the classes: the fighter and rogue don't feel like fighter and rogue respectively, e.g. fighter uses shockwaves and superpowers that can easily be considered magic and feel little different to the caster gameplay; story is your very generic "Evil imprisoned below the dungeon" storyline; etc... Sadly, the result of this is that by 50% of the game you'll be bored and beating the game will feel like a shore.

So all in all, if you're a hack'n'slash junky that loves the genre, played all the classics and is looking for more, buy this and you'll probably like it. But if you only played Classic Diablo and are now looking for something to delve deeper in the genre and came here because of the Diablo comparison marketing, don't buy this, buy something like Titan Quest or Grim Dawn instead.

47595206.review:
Torchlight was released nine years ago in 2009. I recently beat this game and I can say it was an enjoyable experience. I like the versatility of the hero classes in this game. Usually, it’s hard for me to choose between archers or summoners. The vanquisher class permits both so I happily equipped my heroine with guns and skeleton summoning spells.

Gameplay consists of exploring caves, slaying monsters, and gathering loot. In return, you earn experience points, money, and fame. I like how the fame meter rewards “fame points” for slaying tough monsters. This meter is separate from your experience meter granting you an alternative method of developing your skill tree. This game’s resemblance to Diablo is uncanny. Like the original Diablo, you start off in one town and travel deeper into the recesses of a mine. There are approximately eight different themes for the 35 levels which tend to drag. Most monsters including the final boss, remind me of the enemies found in Diablo 2 but some look goofy.

I like the soundtrack but I wish the savage beatings and death screams of my pummeled enemies sounded more pronounced. The game assigns you a pet who serves as an ally and fights with you. You can morph your pet into a monster using pet food. The pet morphing concept is interesting except you barely get to use this mechanic during the campaign. The only way to morph your pet is by obtaining food from fish holes which are rare. Why not let pet food drop while fighting? Despite minor complaints, this game's 16 hour adventure is worth a try. Get the game on sale, and enjoy.

47407978.review:
I keep trying to like this game but I can't do it. 

The game is just boring. I don't give a crap about any of the characters and couldn't even tell you a single one of their names. 

The combat is also boring. I usually like games that involve a lot of grinding, but it feels like its all you do in this game and there is no challenge to it. All you do is enter a dungeon that is made up of recycled rooms from the last dungeon you were in, and room by room, grab a patrol of mobs and wipe them out in 3 secs flat. Grab next group, wipe them in 3 secs. Repeat until dungeon is clear. Repeat in the next dungeon. Then the next. I've done it for 34 floors of the main dungeon hoping for something interesting to happen. Nothing yet though.

Also pet/friendly minion pathing sucks and they will get stuck on terrain frequently. There also doesn't seem to be a lot of visual feedback when it comes to friendlies getting damaged. You can't see how much health your minions have (other than your pet companion), and due to the large amount of enemies on screen, you will lose your friendlies in the mix. The only way to tell if your minions are dead is when all the enemies stop and come straight after you. Then you know it's time to recast your minions. Another thing is that there is no visual feedback when you are being attacked by enemies. The only thing that happens is that your health lowers. It will only flash red when you are literally a single hit away from dying. I wish it would flash red every time your character is hit.

On the plus side the game is stable and I've never experienced a crash. The art style is alright too. 

Overall, I don't understand the hype this game gets, and there are way better gaming options for the price.

45696269.review:
[h1] Torchlight (2009) [/h1]

A decent Hack & Slasher for Diablo fans. Sadly, with a little more than a fair share of issues and other unpleasantries.

[b] What's fine about Torchlight: [/b]

[list]
[*]It's perfect entertainment if watching numbers grow is your thing
[*]Pushing through with all three classes grants the mild impression of playing three different games
[*]Quite addictive
[*]Impressive visuals for an indie release
[*]It's actually 3D
[*]The soundtrack. The sound effects. The voiceovers. Audio is easily this game's best quality
[/list]

[b] What's wrong with Torchlight: [/b]

[list]
[*]The targeting system is the absolute number one reason for dying in this game. Enemy hitboxes do not correspond to their size, e.g. the bigger the enemy is, the harder it is to target. A deal breaker if you're not a patient person
[*]After completing the storyline, the only thing to do here is chasing after stuff you don't need
[*]The storyline is a pale shadow of what's going on in the sequel, Torchlight II
[*]According to one of the achievements, you're supposed to be able to beat this game in just under 5 hours. Can be a problem if you're expecting immersion
[*]Socketables are seriously underpowered and don't offer any level of real tinkery
[*]The game may crash if the player switches dungeon floors and views inventories while the pet is in town
[*]The Antialiasing toggle in Options makes absolutely no difference in quality, it just cuts performance by half (tested with AMD)
[*]The idea of having an item disenchanted. I mean, a failed attempt to pay for an enchant and have nothing happen is bad enough
[*]You won't get much work done without a wagonload of health potions cluttering your inventory. Skills and spells don't make that much of a difference in terms of damage avoidance
[*]The critters your pet can be shapeshifted into don't feel like they're doing much better in combat as compared to the default dog or cat
[*]A bestiary would be nice
[*]The item naming system isn't bulletproof, to say the least
[*]As is the pause view with the camera rotating around the character (press Enter)
[*]Enemy factions barely differ from one another in terms of mechanics
[*]Items lack sell price variance depending on vendor type (e.g. one would expect fetching a better price for weapons from the blacksmith than any other seller, but it's not the case here)
[*]The Shadow Vault exists only for the reason of being a grindbox. Again, laughable rewards from Valeria and Gar
[*]Fame doesn't do anything other than double your skill point output. As it increases, it should at least unlock otherwise unavailable content like special quests with unique mechanics
[*]After hitting level 100 of a character, you stop earning experience and skill points. Renders the most powerful items in the game unusable, unless you pass them down as heirlooms and spend XP accordingly with another character
[*]And, of course, even if an heirloom is passed down, your succeeding character still needs to meet its requirements. This makes retiring high level characters pointless
[*]Certain skills and spells, both on player and enemy side, occassionally have no effect on use (e.g. Heal All fails very often)
[*]Certain skills only work with specific weapon types equipped AND selected, which in the skill's description is stated poorly or not at all
[*]The pet returning from town notification. It's really unnecessary as a game stopping middle-of-screen popup and disrupts combat badly
[*]High enough Knockback can push enemies out of bounds, making them invulnerable to ranged damage and not drop loot on death. This may potentially block the player from completing a quest due to lack of the required item
[*]Achievements don't progress in Offline Mode, e.g. if the player was disconnected from the Internet while fulfilling the requirement. Particularly painful with events such as reaching maximum Fame or taking down bosses, because the achievement is missed and becomes unobtainable with the current character
[/list]

[b] Why I recommend giving Torchlight a shot nonetheless: [/b]

Other than because it's the prequel to a magnificent sequel, I honestly have no idea. This game is the bastard offspring of good Dev and bad QA.

[b] Rating: [/b]

7/10 Video
9/10 Audio
7/10 Storyline
2/10 Side Content
8/10 Stability
4/10 Playability

6/10 Overall

45179310.review:
Kiddy diablo game, very simplified

Edit: Im boycotting Diablo/Blizzard/Hong Kong drama so I came back to give this game another chance. Ive gone through the whole story this time, but I still stand by my original description. 

Just so you know what youre getting yourself into:

1. There are 3 classes total: warrior, mage, archer. About a third of each skill tree is the same between them. For example, all 3 classes have a skill that increases bow/crossbow damage, all 3 classes have a skill that increases experience/gold gain, all 3 classes have a skill that improves armor, etc.

2. You can also buy generic skills like "fireball," "haste," and "summon skeleton." These are categorized as "offensive skills" and "defensive skills," and are different than the "class skills" in your skill tree.

3. The dungeons are repetitive. Three floors of the same dungeon and a boss at the end, followed by (change scenery) three floors of the same dungeon and a boss at the end. You get a waypoint after the boss.

4. In addition to experience, you get "Fame" for completing quests and killing elite mobs. Ive gone through the entire game and I still dont know what Fame does.

5. You have a permanent pet dog or cat. It doesnt help much in combat but it does double your inventory space, and you can send it to town for 2 minutes to sell everything in the pet's inventory. It would be a convenience...if town portal scrolls didnt drop from almost every mob you kill.

6. Enemies are generics: "commander" minions that summon or revive or buff other minions, annoying quick enemies and large tanky trolls. Nothing you havent seen in an rpg before.

7. You cant remap youre keys. You are stuck with playing the 1-9 numbers, entire length of the keyboard.

I RECOMMEND THIS GAME UNDER ONE CONDITION; IT IS PLAYED BY A 6 YEAR OLD WITH FREAKISHLY LONG FINGERS.

44977698.review:
A much more user-friendly and colorful version of Diablo. Not gonna lie, I actually prefer this over the Blizzard's version of a dungeon crawler. Shifting gears here for a sec; I love the Diablo series, but it gets mundane, especially with the final installment. I just felt it was unnecessary to pay for more content on a dated game that you already paid full price for. Sad that this is what gaming has come down to. Incompletion, micro-transactions, loot crates and pay-to-play/pay-to-win features. I'm a bit guilty of forking cash over to some games, like Neverwinter, but it's not really forced. Whereas with older games, such as Torchlight, you don't feel the need to purchase more content to complete the game. 

The game itself is addicting. The grapics are of course, older, but the story is amazing. The controls are easy and the animations are fluid. I want to say this is like a more childish version of Diablo with its attention-grabbing vibrancy, but it's still violent and a bit gorey. Tons of promising gear and loot to boot as well upon defeating bosses and basically shooting up the environment. There's of course, weapon racks to loot, barrels and vases, etc to attack to reach the sweet treasures inside. Lots of skills to play with as well. Really, there's a lot to compare Torchlight and Diablo with, and I can go on. But you'll just have to see for yourselves!

 In conclusion, Torchlight  is a must if you like these types of dungeon crawling games. Plus, you can't really say no to games from Perfect World. Honestly, I waited until the game was on sale. Even grabbed the second one, too!

As much as I loved very much most of the game, there are serious balance issues - why would the last boss be impossible to kill on Very Hard if it's your very first playthrough? I usually start games on the highest / higher difficulty, and I was very sad to have a nice difficulty curve up till the last boss - which then forced me to additional 10h of grinding before I could beat him (without any mods). 

Other than that, the combat is fun, the game plays simple and easy, it's very enjoyable and the grind isn't too tiring - perfect to have something playing in the background (a podcast or something) while you slash through hordes of enemies!

44083046.review:
This game is the only rogue like I actually like, because not only the game is direct about looting and killing things, but also It has side dungeons that can be done.

It's simplicity turns the gameplay favorable for those who puts their hands in it, and the variety of builds It allows you to make through skills, equipments and status turns the game into the recipe to an awesome open game.

There is even dungeon scrolls you may find for sale at the town, when using it, spawns a random dungeon where the monsters inside have around the level of the scroll, that can not only be used for leveling up, gaining fame and equipments, but also to remove part of the monotomy of the main quest, but even though those kinds of dungeons exists in the game, the game itself could try to scale the main world dungeons to around the player level when the player has played several maps of those dungeons, because you will become overpowered to the dungeons after playing for some time.

The mods in the game are not in great variety, but installing them increments a lot in the gameplay.

Beside this game doesn't contains multiplayer or a part of the things that Torchlight 2 brings, this game is casual enough to hook you playing for a long time when you want to pass the time. Also, there is the most awesome part of this game, the summons from the alchemist stays alive for a reeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeally long time, so you don't need to keep casting it again, that's one of the best things this game brought, which should have on Torchlight 2 aswell.

What I say is, what are you waiting for?

42499446.review:
I bought Torchlight in December 2013 from Steam and have been playing it off and on for these many years.  Very enjoyable and repeatable gameplay.  If you've played FATE it's similar in playstyle.  You descend levels, (35 in main quest, limited in a couple others and then there is a never-ending dungeon descent if you're so inclined to never let go of the game).  Once you get past all of the main quests the never-ending dungeon is just an exercise in fetch-this-item or kill-that-guy with a repeat of all the dungeon environments you had encountered during the main quests. A number of them need to be done to complete some of the achievements.  

When Torchlight II came out that version consumed most of my time.  More recently, I decided to complete all of that game's achievements.  When finally done, (phew!!!!), I came back to the original Torchlight and noticed I had only about 1/2 of the achievements and decided to work on them.  (Yes...a glutton for punishment am I).

After many hours and run-throughs I finally got the achievements down to a final three.  I find these three very odd as I need to add the following: 1 mod, 5 mods, 10 mods and use these total of ten mods on one character at the same time. I do use mods when I find ones I like but I consider them a cheat and to me a cheat is not an achievement...lol 

I downloaded and used one, can't even remember what it did and didn't see anything change in the game.  But I now need to add  9 more to complete all the achievements.  I have a copy of the app file I will use later in case there's a conflict among the mods I choose.

THE REVIEW:

Both Torchlight games have THE SMOOTHEST GAMEPLAY of any game I've ever played.  The attention to detail is noteworthy.  Some examples that stand out for me:
  
~A lamp swinging slowly back and forth up near the fishing hole in town..lots of other items showing motion, as well
~In Torchlight I the transition between acts is done with a simple visit by one of the main 
  NPCs and a "note from Alric's diary" to advance to the next act--both cutscenes are a very 
  quick read and unobstrusive.  (I find long cutscenes irritating, especially if I can't skip them!)
~Dungeon levels have detailed views of levels below and around
~Water effects are pretty 
~My characters are very responsive to all commands
~My pet has three levels of behavior: (1) aggressive, (2) mostly attacks what targets me, (3) passive   (All stances work) 
~Pet can be fed different types of fish that will change it's form for a time or permanently to a melee or magic-casting creature
~Can send pet to town to sell items and there are add-ons to jewelry, armor and skills to shorten the time the pet is gone
~The look of clothing changes on character when adding new items
~The AOEs and melee effects are varied and satisfying when executed--the hitbox is spot on
~Monsters' effects are the same as above
~Sound effects are appropriate for locations and actions
~Monsters are very responsive and even in a mob of them they each act as an individual with a thought for their own safety in mind
~Obvious to me a lot of thought went into how each type of monster fights...it's not just a mob rushing at you...instead, each monster type in that mob is coming at you in their own way and react to your countermeasures their own way
~Sooooo many useful armors, weapons, jewelry and socketables to find/choose from!
~Nice touch to be able to enhance weapons, armor, jewelry from the Enchanter.  Improved in Torchlight II when Enchanter was split into two types, one who can enhance an item, another who only adds sockets to items

I recommend:
 
~Torchlight I: For a plain o'l hack 'n slash-dungeon crawl game...nicely done!
~Torchlight II:  Multiply the above with so much more to do, explore and fight...perfection of the genre!

Runic---I miss you!  :(

42232224.review:
[h1][b]Highly Recommended[/b][/h1]

In spite of its age, the game still looks and plays great. A classic aRPG, that I feel every gamer who is getting into, or is already into, hack & slash aRPG's should play, at least once. Not just to Ordrak, vut into the Vault. 

Yes, the game has bugs. Most are minor, just a momentary annoyance. Some are more significant, like not being able to complete side quests due to the quest item always being one quest behind. Yes, I have that in the game... I cannot complete Hatch quests. I'll hope my next playthrough does not pop the same bug. Or I'll break down and install a community Mod to fix it. Even if I have to create the Mod myself.

Yeah, I am a fangirl. I'll go to great lengths to continue enjoying this game. 

Runs great on a 6 year old medium range toaster gaming rig, custom build. Not the best machine, not the worst. 60 fps all the way, some slight hitching during REALLY busy battles with a sheetload of effects going on. Not often though. Usually when I get slammed by 3-4 champions and their mobs all at once and have to spam spells and spam minions. But, it does happen sometimes. 

Again, be aware the game has some bugs, and always has. Since Runic's publisher shut their studio down, it is unlikely they will ever be completely fixed, unless independent community Modders decide to create new mods to fix them. There are some already out there, you just have to search the old online forums and modding sites to find them.

Replayability? YES. Tons of it.

Worth full price? YES. Absolutely. But always good if you can find it and Torchlight II on sale in a bundle (which happens regularly).

The game is whimsical and funny, while being gritty and dirty at the same time. A truly wonderful blend of feels, with spectacular art and effects, that have actually aged quite well. This is the second account I have owned this (and TL II) on. woth hundreds of hours or each game, And hundreds more to come. Good for long sessions, or for short sessions, as long as you are smart about where and when you save. 

My opinions. Your Mileage May Vary. Widely.

Playing on the highest difficulty level still presents a challenge. You have your pet to fight with you and send to town to sell excess gear, a homage to Fate which is where this game originates from.

41937872.review:
It seems that when a new genre springs into being, that’s when the biggest deluge of imitators tends to appear. That was certainly the case if you look at the field of ARPGs, as a huge number of them rose in the shadow of the original Diablo rather than either of its sequels. Torchlight wasn’t a contemporary of Diablo but even coming a decade later the influence is clear, and unsurprising given the talent behind it at Runic Games. It followed the pattern so faithfully, in fact, that it failed to innovate in ways that have allowed other ARPGs to flourish in the same period. That’s not to say Torchlight is a bad game, but rather one where the gulf between it and better games is evident.

The town of Torchlight was founded atop an enormous vein of ember, a pretty standard mystical mineral that can enchant or corrupt things depending on what the plot requires. Mining the stuff was going just great before evil monsters began pouring out of the tunnels, and the chaos has claimed your mentor somewhere deep beneath the world. Being a fine, strapping hero you descend into the mines with your trusty (and capable) pet to fight, loot, explore, loot, fish, loot, and maybe get to the bottom of whatever’s going on. And collect some loot while you’re at it.

You’ll notice the connections to Diablo 1 the moment you load into town, and not just because the BGM there is a send-up of the Tristram theme. The structure of the game is identical, with you descending into a single, expansive, multi-level dungeon beneath the town to score loot and press on to the bosses in your way. Back in town you can sell your junk, buy new junk, mash your old junk into new junk, and give your junk new traits. It’s a familiar cycle, one that’s been expanded upon by virtually every ARPG that came after Diablo 1 (including its sequels), except for those that followed faithfully in its footsteps. I don’t consider this disqualifying, but taken alongside its other shortcomings it’s not a good look.

Combat is where you’ll spend the half of the game where you’re not futzing with loot, and it’s in a rough place between D1 and modern sensibilities. You’re certainly not snapped to a grid in these bright, colorful maps but your skills remain very stiff and not terribly exciting to use. I’ve gotten the farthest with the archer-style character who thankfully gets guns from the steampunk trappings of the setting, but ended up with no skills more interesting than exploding or ricocheting shots. The skill trees borrow from Diablo 2 in fact, expecting you to dump points into a main skill to spam all the time forever and ever. And keep in mind you’re going to be killing lots of very standard goblins and spiders with these skills, albeit very elaborately-designed ones.

What Torchlight has going for it, and what can save you from burning out on it after just a few hours, is a load of little side features that still support your ultimate goal of… well, finding loot, really. Your pet is a pretty big selling point on its own, starting you off with a doggie or kitty that you can eventually transmogrify into all kinds of adorable horrors. They can fight alongside you, get equipped with accessory items, hold extra items for you, and even cart junk back to town to sell while you forge ahead in the depths. There’s also fishing of all things that can turn up special items and buffs, and a portal to randomized challenge maps that can earn you important gear upgrades if you can make it to the end.

None of these elements are unique to Torchlight, of course, leaving the game feeling like a title cobbled together from the most visible bits of other games. Even the look is heavily cribbed from World of Warcraft, with great big technicolor shapes and over-designed armors and enemies. Time has only made these comparisons less favorable as the genre has moved forward with titles like Path of Exile and Grim Dawn, leaving Torchlight to stand as one of the better imitators of an outmoded game. That’s not the brightest crown to wear but it’s better than nothing, which is really the nicest thing I can say about this game in terms of a recommendation.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11322459/]curation page[/url]!

41342220.review:
I went into this game with low expectations and I was still let down.

Although a fun slash & hack dungeon delver at first, it gets repetitive rather quickly. 
The level scaling seems off. First you're way too strong and breeze through everything and suddendly your using potions left and right just to survive. I'd expect a gradual rise of difficulty with higher levels, but there was nothing gradual about it.
I reached the "End Boss" in a fairly decent amount of time but with the level I was at, couldn't even make a scratch. I spent more time grinding the same dungeon again and again to level up, than actually getting to the End Boss. It was extremely tedious, as you can imagine.

Also, I didn't play this game for the story, because that's obviously not the focus of the game, but even considering that, it was bad and generic. As was the voice acting.

It's not all bad, to me it was all a bit underwhelming. I'd recommend this to a younger audience, maybe to kids that want to get into RPGs or haven't played a lot of computer games yet.

41141617.review:
[h1]Comentario Robótico-Analítico: "Torchlight"[/h1]

No soy el primero en decirlo y quizás estés cansado de escucharlo, pero es mejor pasar de largo y jugar Torchlight 2 directamente. Esta primera entrega es mala y dejó mucho margen a la mejora.

A ver, los ARPG son en su mayoría juegos muy repetitivos y la novedad tiende a ser casual, sin embargo pocas veces hay tanto descaro como con Torchlight. Su secuela, tanto como otras entregas del género, ofrecen ligeras formas de variedad en la experiencia, así la monotonía se ve opacada; en el caso de Torchlight la monotonía es tal que podría figurar coo demo técnica. Es una sola mazmorra con un único lobby, y la experiencia no difiere de las bases más simplificadas de su género. A efectos prácticos, todos los defectos de Torchlight se deben a lo mismo; es muy básico, y esto se manifiesta en los sets o las habilidades.

Tuve que empezarlo tres veces porque las primeras dos sufrí un softlock absurdo, por suerte fue cerca del comienzo del juego así que no tuve que repetir mucho.

[b]¿En conclusión?[/b] No puedo recomendarlo, la secuela es muy superior y si no, hay alternativas excelentes.

Your basic hack & slash, with minimal story and even less interesting game play.

The entire thing is just one long "kill everything with your 1 real attack", "find the next key".  The entire "world" is literally nothing but deeper and deeper levels below the 1 town you never leave.

Even on "very hard" the game is very easy, nearly everything always falling over in one mouse click, maybe two.  Typically whole rooms of bad guys fall over with a single click.  The entire game is that way...until the final boss, who isn't particularly interesting, but will under even the best of conditions take forever to kill in the most annoying fight ever.

Save yourself the trouble of bothering with the boss.  Just watch the "fight" on YouTube once you get there, then Uninstall and play with your belly button lint because that's more fun than Torchlight.

40142090.review:
This is Diablo for kids. 

The core idea of this game is to be a "read story - build gear - slay monsters". And this is based on Diablo game mechanics and music. However, there are many asides:
1) The story is too shallow and hardly envolving;
2) The game mechanics is overly simplified and it is too easy to become OverPowered - which actually happned to me. 
3) The monsters do not offer much of a challenge and become repetitive and boring.
4) Though the resemblance with Diablo makes it nostalgic at first, soon enough you start comparing and find out it is far from being so good, even comparing with Diablo 1.

But I will still recommend bacause:
1) I guess I would find it good enough if I haven't me Diablo in my life;
2) the first 20 hours of playing were actually enjoyable.

Buy it if it is on sale and if you have kids and want to show them a soft hack-slash RPG.

39200247.review:
Do you like playing Diablo single player? If you do, then Torchlight is for you.

Made from Ex Blizzard staff, torchlight is a hack and slash that has you delve into the dungeons below the town to destroy creatures corrupted by ember and stop an evil force from destroying the world. You can pick from 3 different classes that match what was available in Diablo (a Warrior, Rouge and Magic user, though they are renamed to the Destroyer, Vanquisher and Alchemist).

While offering many of the same options as diablo, it does have a few differences that sets it apart. While each dungeon is random (same as Diablo) and the characters skill progressions works much the same as Diablo 2 (some skills feed other skills) you do have a few new options. Your character can have a pet assigned, that helps by sending loot back to down. There is a fishing minigame where the characters can use the fish they capture for different effects, and to transform their pet into something different. You can at any point retire your hero, which grants an heirloom to your new character with some of their skills and stats, which in effect servers as a new game+ mode (which can be accessed at any time as once you pick a difficulty level its locked for that character.

The difficulty varies wildly, depending on which class and skills you pick up, what loot you find, and the base difficulty. I played the Destroyer and found it quite fun and his skills were quite useful and suited for my play style, however on the hardest difficulty kiting was needed to progress. It got to a point where I was only able to kill a few monsters, retreat/heal before jumping back into the fray, as before my character was wading through an entire level of monsters and rarely using healing items. I’m not sure if I was under leveled for the area or needed better loot, but it got hard fast in a way that diablo never did. Don’t even get me started on the end boss. That was a nightmare.

The game offers native support for custom mods, which can be accessed at any point from the town map.

Graphically the game looks like a cuter version of Diablo- everything looks cartoony. The game isn’t aiming for a dark and depressing feel so the tone works quite well (even if you are trekking through Ruins, Crypts and other gloomy places). Similarly, the music and sound is the same, instead of screams and roars of creatures you get grunts and the effects of weapons clashing over the top of a relatively mild music score (again think of the Diablo music score with a lot of string instruments). A lot of the enemies are just reskins, with more hit points and extra abilities as you go deeper. I think the total amount of unique enemies (not including the re-skinned variants) sits somewhere between diablo 1 and 2 (but closer to 1).

You can gamble loot, and enchant items much like the Diablo series, and there are hatch quests to do if you want to take a break from the standard dungeon. If you have an itch to play something Diablo-ish but don’t want to play diablo then this is the game for you

If you are chasing 100% achievements then expect to become a master of this with multiple runs required, 5 hours speed runs, very hard hardcore mode, a run from each character type, hatch quest plus requiring mods to be installed.

39171032.review: Pretty fun game made by the leads of Diablo I and Diablo II. Simple concept of going down floors in a dungeon with there being a boss normally before the dungeon type changes. Reach the end of a certain dungeon type and unlock a warp to town. The game scales exceptionally well and might be a bit on the easy side. Then you hit the last area and the green skeletons become very annoying and ramp up the difficulty level a bit. I wasn't even concerned with death until that area. Unfortunately, the last boss doesn't scale with the rest of the game and is disasterous. Expect to die on the last boss. Often. Especially if you didn't build you character right. Why games don't let you respec is beyond me. With the last boss the health doesn't replenish on it when you die so you just use the warp and go back to fighting it. The dumb part of this is that it's such a ramp up in difficulty compared to the rest of the game I could see people just tossing in the towel and being done with the game. Overall, I enjoyed the game, and I am looking forward to trying Torchlight II in the future.

38904565.review:
[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Good, solid isometric ARPG which, at the time of publishing, helped to fill the gap between Diablo 2 and 3, as there weren't many decent ARPG's around (Titan Quest being a noteable exception). Outdated now as there are better alternatives in the same genre, but still a good game that you can safely pick up when it's on sale.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
I'm assuming that everybody who reads this at least knows what an action RPG is, so I won't go into the mechanics of the game too deeply, since it doesn't stray far from the general mechanics of games in this genre. Basic attacks, special skills, potions, gems, randomly generated loot, it's all there.

In the game, you play as either a Destroyer (melee combat warrior), Alchemist (mage-type) or Vanquisher (ranged warrior). You arrive in the town of Torchlight, built on top of a big Ember vein (Ember being a kind of ore with properties to imbue people and items with magical power). The town is in trouble, since monsters start pouring out of the nearby mine, and one of the sages, Master Alric, is missing.

So down you go into the mines, where you quickly discover that below the mines, there's a huge dungeon that's basically a "layer cake" of different civilizations. As you delve deeper into the dungeon, and defeat several sub-bosses, the story progresses until you find the root of all evil at the bottom of the dungeon. This feels very, very much like Diablo 1, and in that way, it was quite outdated already upon release, since games like Diablo 2 and Titan Quest (released before Torchlight 1) already offered a far bigger, vaster world.

Regardless, Torchlight 1 has everything a basic ARPG needs and it does everything quite well. Some things that make (/made) it stand out are the fact that your pet is of actual use instead of it being just a visual addition (you can send it to town to sell loot, so you don't have to go yourself and you can continue going through the dungeon), it has great graphics and music (at least at the time of publishing), there's a great variety in monsters (one thing that I found lacking in Titan Quest), and that it was one of the first ARPGs to have an actual endgame (the endless dungeon) once you finished the main storyline. On the downside, it doesn't have a multiplayer mode, which a lot of players regard as a serious omission.

[h1]Pros and cons[/h1]
+ fresh visual style and good music & sound effects (by Matt Uelmen, who also did the music for Diablo 1 and 2)
+ nice mix of fantasy and steampunk
+ good amount of replayability with different classes, skills, items, difficulty settings and the "endless dungeon"
+ a lot of variety in items and monsters
+ big, unique boss monsters
+ a pet with multiple uses (attack / defend / sell goods at town)
+ moddable game with quite a lot of good mods available
+ fishing (which doesn't do much for me, but I guess it's a "thing" for some people :) )

- not much of a storyline
- small inventory size
- the worlds are a bit too big, so gameplay gets a bit repetitive before you reach the final boss
- no multiplayer mode
- trillbot :)

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
It's a good game with quite a lot of replay value and definitely worth the price, although I'd advise to pick it up on sale. You can still get enough fun and gamplay out of it, even if you do only one playthrough. It can't really compete with more recent games in the same genre, though. If given the choice, go for Torchlight 2 or Grim Dawn instead, which are more developed in pretty much every single way. Or, if you like complex ARPGs with huge skill trees and even more game mechanics, go for Path of Exile.

38236256.review:
Having played both Torchlight 1 and 2, I would rate the first game below average. Compared to Torchlight 2 this is a really boring and repetitive game, with recycled monsters used continuously, some broken and in need of fix mobs (Accolytes) that will 1 shot you unless you play melee with maxed out defenses.

The maps are mostly the same, featuring a dungeon or a castle like theme, there is scarce diversity in maps, the enemies after a point are mostly the same, few bosses were interesting or unique looking, the active effects which you have to keep track of and renew every 20 seconds are way too many and make the combat feel like a chore.

The campaign is also very short (8 hours), the story is tiny and uninteresting and the optional end game is a 100-floor dungeon using again the same recycled maps and enemies.

Unfortunately this is a really dull and monotonous game and I do NOT recommend buying it in full price. Only perhaps for die-hard ARPG fans and even then for free or on a 3$ sale like I did. 
Do not be fooled by the "Very Positive" reviews this game has on Steam. This is mostly because Torchlight 2 is such a big hit, it affected its predecessor aswell.
Speaking of which, the second installment in the series, Torchlight 2, is a really great game which solves almost all of the problems mentioned above, along with adding unique and immersive maps and epic boss fights. I definitely suggest giving the second game a try.

38181287.review:
Greetings,

this review is quite late, as this game came out in 2009 and i am writing this at the end of 2017. 
If you like action RPGs and if you liked Diablo 1, then this is the right thing for you. 

What you get:
The 3 archetypes of classes: Warrior, Archer/Rogue, Mage. Each class has 3 destinctive talent trees.
I only played the mage Class. Every talent tree felt very unique and well balanced on it's own and followed a specific theme (Caster tree with insane mana regeneration and a lot of more damaging spells and CC spells; a Summoner tree with lots of minios and talents to enhance them and a Melee tree, with armor enhancing, a magic shield and close-up abilities).

The base game does not support resetting of spent talent points, but there is a mod for that.

If the loot lord is not with you, then you can buy stuff at the "gambler". Basically you can pick an unidentified item for a reasonable price. The item will have a certain quality, although the rolls on it are random. 
Would only suggest that for weapons, because you get a good dps on it and thats kinda the most important thing on weapons. On armor it is too much hit or miss for my taste.

If you feel like playing different classes, then you get a shared stash in town, that is accessable at level 1.

If you want to enhance your gear, then you can also put random enchants on items at the town enchanter, to improve items.

Storywise you get the "Diablo 1" package. There is a mine at the town "Torchlight" and there is bad stuff going on in that mine. You have to fight all the way down to the big villan, with some minor "plottwists".

The graphic is still ok up today and it has a more comic like approach.

If you like ARPGs and havent stumbled on Torchlight yet, then it is worth your money.

36634144.review:
Its been a few months since I last played, so please excuse my lack of correct verbage as pertains to the game. :)

LOVE: style of animation, character and pet choices, lots of choices at the shops; various "shops" etc in the main area are close together... not needlessly running back-and-forth and all over the place; also nice to send my pet back to sell my treasure so I can keep playing; really detailed ability to upgrade both with items bought, fishing, gems, and other ways, lots and lots of skills and special powers to choose from. Especially love the "shared treasure chest" between characters, just wish it were bigger earlier. 

DON'T LOVE: although there are many, many levels, the locations are limited; I also HATE going to the "wizard" to take a chance on upgrading and then losing all of the pluses on the item forever... should be able to buy my way out... that is extremely frustrating and has caused me to quit the game when I've lost my best weapon.

I WISH: It would be awesome if I were given a choice of upgrades somehow: what if I were to come across some magic dude in my travels and because I do something great for him he offers me a CHOICE of five improvements? Or what if I go into a shop and instead of paying for a "general-you-never-know-what-will-happen" upgrade or a completely different weapon or armor, I could ask for something specific to be done to my stuff? I know, I have the gems and skills... but that is still somewhat limiting.  

Despite the negatives, I love the game, have multiple characters, and have come back to play it repeatedly over the years. Also have Torchlight 2 and love it. These games are all about grabbing the treasure.

Overall you can relax playing the game and I'd recommend it to anybody who likes Diablo-styled games.

36199015.review:
I found this title pleasantly engrossing. Engrossing, not challenging. Because Torchlight is not an action game (if defined as a high-stakes button-masher requiring wicked reflexes and spatial awareness). Half the time, I'm not even watching the screen during battles. I'm spamming magic bouncy arrows and monitoring my twin health and mana gauges.

Torchlight is a resource management simulation of a dungeon crawler. You spend most of your time comparing armor and weapon stats, shifting gear from place to place and optimizing loadouts. The dungeon crawling and fighting parts of the game are merely resource harvesting for the ecosystem of destruction that surrounds my Amazon warrior (aka a "Vanquisher").

And perhaps your experience playing the wildly randomized world of Torchlight will be different. As for me, I selected my Vanquisher - a chick who shoots guns, crossbows and bows - on normal difficulty and just started augmenting her native stats and abilities without branching much. A quarter through the game, she was noticeably overpowered. Halfway through the game, and she was a force of nature. My gun one-shot all but the largest monsters, and my pet cat endlessly spawned a hoard of zombies to handle crowd control, aggro and dirty fightin'.

One or two times during a single dungeon level, I paused to load my cat up with gear and send it back to town to sell it at the market. While it's gone, I endured what I jokingly call "hard mode," actually having to carefully draw enemy aggro, aim my weapon at specific targets and flank my foes. I could not WAIT until that damn cat gets back.

You really want to play Torchlight as an action game (otherwise, I would have selected the fighter ... er ... "Destroyer"). The enemies are all pallet-swapped idiots. The dungeons are repetitive. And the bosses are a joke. But the loot, oh my GAWD, the loot. Torchlight strokes that same mental tick as bottom-feeding browser games like Farmville. Just one more shiny thing. Just one more click ...

I received this for free when i picked up Torchlight II a long while ago, but hadn't actually played it until recently.

A very solid game. It has a much more simplistic approach than something like Path of Exile (another arpg I would recommend), so it's a lot easier to hit the ground running in this game and just enjoy it. You have 3 classes to choose from when naming your character, depending on what sort of playstyle you prefer. There are stat points that you gain as you level up (generally these should go towards your main damage stat and/or whatever requirements you need to wear your upgrades). You also get skill points, which are fewer in number, to level up different attacks, spells, and passive abilities on your passive tree. Once you figure out what you want your character to do, it's a simple thing to allocate points. 

The artstyle is very much cartoonish; however it does not detract from the gameplay (unless you're the sort of person who gets hung up on that sort of thing). There are four difficulties to match your level of experience with arpg type games, so feel free to pick this up even if you're an inexperienced player. There is also plenty to do after you've beaten the final boss: like completing achievements, crafting endgame gear, and grinding higher level monsters.

If you're looking for a fun, single-player arpg experience, give this game a shot.

35212994.review:
This game is good for a couple hours of entertainment. But nothing more.
Gonna stay on the positive side and rate 6/10 because I did enjoy it for some bits.

What you got here is a pretty looking game. Seems you can play three different characters with different styles.
I played only one. Do not get the feeling I would have a different experience/story playing the other two.

I did very much enjoy the first couple of hours. You level up, get new spells and abilities. You are able to customize your dude a bit so you can play different styles every few floors. But in the end you get pretty strong and you can just rightclick through anything that comes at you without having to be arsed about anything else except mana.
Expect to click those mousebuttons like a maniac.

Unfortunately... there's hardly any story to the game. The most an NPC will talk to you is 7 lines or so. You get 0 connection with your character as he's annoying as fuck. All he ever says is 'My pack is full'. Because your inventory space is nonexistant. After a couple hours that really becomes irksome the repetitive message of how your inventory is always full. 

So.... your inventory is always full. You have a pet, and the pet has a backpack. Yes. You can toss all the crud you don't use onto your pet and make him run to town and sell it. That's a relieve atleast. The pet does help a little in battle, but you don't miss him much when he's off to town. You can customize your pet as well, he can wear a necklace, a pair of rings and learn two magic spells. I felt that was a nice touch, but it's not really that game making or breaking with how it been executed.

Same as the way you can enchant weapons, gem them or upgrade items. The options are there.. but did I feel the need to use them? not really. At some point the game is just done, and you can continue.. but I did not get a feeling of reward. It just became dull playing with an enchanted weapon.

I did like the fact you get to discover what the game has to offer on your own. Didn't really notice anything of a tutorial. It does have mouseover tips, but no popups that'll tell you what to do (not that I remember). So it's fun to discover what is possible and not. Found out about the pet's backpack a bit later on, was happy to find that, and then later the option to make the mutt run to town and pawn the clutter.

At some point the story just seemed to be over. There's more quests you can do. But at this point you kinda miss the guidance. There's no indication of where you need to be. For example you need to find an 'Ember' of some sorts in the Necropolis. There's no place named Necropolis. You can go into a mine, or some tomb or whatever it's named. And it won't name a floor number or indication on minimap, you can't quest track. And at this point the quests do not add anything anymore, not for me anyways. There's no way to find out in the game where this fucking Necropolis is. Unless you use google and youtube.

At some point I did not get the feeling I was making any more progress in the game. It was just more and more of the same. Holding right mouse button and move towards the end of a floor. 

Saw an option to retire my character, as to make him unplayable and leave an item with high value for a next character I would be able to play. But there was no indication that a story would continue. So just gonna asume that it would be more of the same, on a character that looks a tad different and has different attack while you hold your right mousebutton.

I got this game in a pack, torchlight, torchlight II and Hob. 

Truly, the game is beautiful, and I did enjoy several hours of playing. But I cannot stand by recommending this game for full price. if at sometime you can score it in a sale I would tell you: go for it.
But don't expect 100+ hours on it. I was done in about 8 and then felt disapointment grow in the 8 following.

Encountered only 1 bug. One where I got stuck. And no way to restart the level or use teleport. All the support was based on windows XP. Did finally manage to translate that to the year 2017, but kinda felt they could've and should've switched on the console option by default.

Torchlight felt to me like a cartoonish Diablo I, with a town you can buy and sell things in, and a dungeon that goes from the beginning floor all the way to the final boss fight. It's a compact game that doesn't take as much time to complete as some action RPGs, and I found that to be a positive. If I enjoy my time with a shorter game, I'll be more encouraged to play it again, which I did, at least once or twice more, to completion, since the game has 3 character classes and I wanted to give them a try.

Each character feels like the classic archetypes: warrior, rogue, and mage, and I had an easy enough time figuring out what skills looked good, and they felt good to use. The game has a sequel, and a lot of people love it, but I actually thought this original game was a lot more enjoyable for me.

33472112.review:
Not a horrible game if you have the patience to get through all of the repetitive levels, but also not a great game.

The art style is what drew me in to this game. I remember playing the demo on the console forever ago and somewhat enjoying it, so I thought I'd try it out while it was on sale. The gameplay is exactly what it looks like in the thumbnails. You spend most of the game beating up enemies with a large array of weapons and magical attacks with different properties.

However, this game is very dumbed down and shallow. The lore and quests are not very deep, and the voice acting is over-done and a bit comical in its style—which can be enjoyable, but is not for everyone. The focus of the game is to beat up monsters inside of ruins, which can be pretty fun if you have the patience to get through the game.

As an RPG, this game lacks many customization options. You have a choice of three types of characters—one of which, the meelee character, is basically obsolete—and an option to have either a pet cat or a pet dog. Other than that, even though there are many items in the game, their properties are ultimately meaningless. The only real stragegy to play the game is to sell old items and buy the most powerful new items. The result is that, even if you spend a lot of time considering how you want to approach the game and saving up money to design specialized weapons to fit your play style, you'll end up cycling through weapons as you progress and your old weapons quickly become obselete. If you play this game, it's best not to put too much thought into your weapons and armor, since they will be replaced by better weapons by the time you make it back to the shop.

The game is not very challenging on any difficulties other than the hardest difficulty, and it doesn't allow you to change your difficulty in a save. However, in this game, difficulty is not exactly something that you want, since this game spawns in the same enemies every time you re-enter a dungeon. Not only this, but the levels are very repetitive and not very meaningful. Each level and boss looks very similar to the last, and you'll end up wishing you could get through the repetitive level design a lot sooner.

If you give the game a little patience and little thought about the meta-game, and can bear the quirky art style, you might enjoy this game, but it can get repetitive and annoying as you go along. I wouldn't recommend this game at the full price (as I got it on sale), but I might recommend it to someone is looking for a simple game that doesn't come from a large franchise that requires a lot of playtime and work to get into.

First of all, I cannot recommend this game at all because it disappointed me in several aspects of its game play. Originally I had hoped to find a similar game to Titan Quest which I used to play for a long time. So having some experience in this genre I started playing hard mode as a melee fighter. Though I wasn't maxing out my stats but testing a lot of skills for their effectiveness, fights (even boss fights) became pretty simple after I had found out that the only necessary skill was the AoE attack spell you get on the first level. Using two additional defensiv buffs and group healing spells for my pet enabled me to kill most creeps with one blow which I didn't even had to aim due to the AoE attack. So most fight were right clicking somewhere one the screen and taking a mana potion when necessary -> pretty boring.

Further cons:

- Your pet cannot die, so you don't have to take any care but can rather use it as a free additional HP buffer. By using its own healing spell it almost imidiately reengaged after fleeing.

- It is quite common to pass a map several time when descending further downstairs. Reusing a map isn't very oringinally.

- There isn't any interesting story or dialog which I wanted to listen to. 

- It doesn't make any sense at all that the player has to fight through the whole dungeon, while after every boss monster this woman is coming through the portal und talking to you.

- There are only 4 completely identical quests - kill the boss monster, klil an arbitrary hero monster, find an ember and raiding an additional dungeon. After finishing one quest you'll get the same one again.

- Costumization of your gear is very limited by just adding up to two embers which don't have a great variability in their effects. 

Pros:

-  I don't have any good pro argument for this game. At least gold isn't completely worthless like it is in Titan Quest because you can enchant your weapons.

32248111.review:
Greetings Everyone!  My next stop was back to Torchlight a dungeon crawler that I feel tries to bring back that classic feeling of the original Diablo.  Overall it succeeds, for its time this was a great dungeon crawler for those wanting a classic feel with some cleaned up mechanics.  I still enjoyed my play through and is a great stepping stone towards Torchlight 2 (another game I highly recommend).

Stay awhile and Listen:  From the town to the indentify scrolls this game feels like the spiritual successor of Diablo and it is an enjoyable experience.  The story isn’t bad either albeit a bit bland (again not necessarily a bad thing for the game’s intent) and although I would have liked to see a bit more to do in the end I can’t complain as the core gameplay is so well done.  If you are trying to show someone classic dungeon crawl this is a better game to start with than some of the originals this game takes from.

Supersize me:  It cannot be understated how involved the mod community is for this game and how much it influences this game.  There is even an achievement for installing a mod and I find myself installing a mod almost immediately.  I know many of you won’t like this but I installed the respec potion mod.  I have never really understood the need for some to insist that choices like this have to be permanent.  Depending on the game it should be as easy as going to a town or as difficult as a month long process.  I just never feel a character (especially when the end game is good) should be permanently punished for a bad decision a new player made 5 minutes into playing.  I digress, give the mods out there a look; an argument could be made that you should probably play the game to completion before installing any to get the vanilla product down but it is your choice.

Ye Olde Classic:  Everything about this game screams classic dungeon crawl, even the difficulty if you decide to crank it up.  This is both to its credit and detriment as there are some issues that are caused by this design philosophy.  Some quality of life features are missing such as minion information:  I enjoy playing minion master type classes and it was hard for me to determine when I needed to respawn minions in the middle of massive battles.  The mini map could use a bit of work as it seems to take inspiration from older dungeon crawlers in this area too (TL2 massively improves upon this) and blends into the scenery.  Draw distance for enemies and even odd instances where enemies would phase in an out for odd reasons (no they weren’t teleporting).  Finally, some players may feel the game was too simple, with very basic leveling system and little to do other than the next level.  I can understand but do not agree with this.

So much of this game takes inspiration from Diablo and I love it, it was a great trek down memory lane.  But, is it worth buying now?  Simply put, yes.  There are some issues that much is obvious but the little issues are well worth the game itself.  If you are dungeon crawler who doesn’t have this game; get it.  It would also be a great buy to get someone into this genre.
